gannet: One of several species of sea birds of the genus Sula, alliedto the pelicans.
guileful: Full of guile; characterized by cunning, deceit, or treachery;guilty.-- Guile"ful*ly, adv.-- Guile"ful*ness, n.
guava: A tropical tree, or its fruit, of the genus Psidium. Twovarieties are well known, the P. pyriferum, or white guava, and P.pomiferum, or red guava. The fruit or berry is shaped like apomegranate, but is much smaller. It is somewhat astringent, butmakes a delicious jelly.
gothic: Of or pertaining to a style of architecture with pointedarches, steep roofs, windows large in proportion to the wall spaces,and, generally, great height in proportion to the other dimensions --prevalent in Western Europe from about 1200 to 1475 a. d. See Illust.of Abacus, and Capital.
ghoul: An imaginary evil being among Eastern nations, which wassupposed to feed upon human bodies. [Written also ghole .] Moore.
glenoid: Having the form of a smooth and shallow depression; sockas, theglenoid cavity, or fossa, of the scapula, in which the head of thehumerus articulates.
ghazi: Among Mohammedans, a warrior champion or veteran, esp. in thedestruction of infidels.
gynophore: The pedicel raising the pistil or ovary above the stamens, asin the passion flower. Lindley.
grid: A grating of thin parallel bars, similar to a gridiron.
grave: (Naut.) To clean, as a vessel's bottom, of barnacles, grass,etc., and pay it over with pitch; -- so called because graves orgreaves was formerly used for this purpose.
gazogene: A portable apparatus for making soda water or aërated liquidson a small scale. Knight.
gladden: To make glad; to cheer; to please; to gratify; to rejoice; toexhilarate.A secret pleasure gladdened all that saw him. Addison.
gibbartas: One of several finback whales of the North Atlantic; -- calledalso Jupiter whale. [Written also jubartas, gubertas, dubertus.]
guitguit: One of several species of small tropical American birds of thefamily Coerebidæ, allied to the creepers; -- called also quit. SeeQuit.
gourmand: A greedy or ravenous eater; a glutton. See Gormand.That great gourmand, fat Apicius B. Jonson.
gherkin: A kind of small, prickly cucumber, much used for pickles.
gerundive: Pertaining to, or partaking of, the nature of the gerund;gerundial.-- n. (Lat. Gram.)
guffaw: A loud burst of laughter, a horse laugh. "A hearty low guffaw."Carlyle.
glowworm: A coleopterous insect of the genus Lampyris; esp., the winglessfemales and larvæ of the two European species (L. noctiluca, and L.splendidula), which emit light from some of the abdominal segments.Like a glowworm in the night, The which hath fire in darkness, nonein light. Shak.
giallolino: A term variously employed by early writers on art, thoughcommonly designating the yellow oxide of lead, or massicot. Fairholt.
grilly: To broil; to grill; hence, To harass. [Obs.] Hudibras.
gard: Garden. [Obs.] "Trees of the gard." F. Beaumont.
grandfather: A father's or mother's father; an ancestor in the next degreeabove the father or mother in lineal ascent. Grandfather longlegs.(Zoöl.) See Dady longlegs.
goat: A hollow-horned ruminant of the genus Capra, of several speciesand varieties, esp. the domestic goat (C. hircus), which is raisedfor its milk, flesh, and skin.
generalize: To form into a genus; to view objects in their relations to agenus or class; to take general or comprehensive views.
giantship: The state, personality, or character, of a giant; -- acompellation for a giant.His giantship is gone somewhat crestfallen. Milton.
gamma rays: Very penetrating rays not appreciably deflected by a magneticor electric field, emitted by radioactive substances. The prevailingview is that they are non-periodic ether pulses differing fromRöntgen rays only in being more penetrating.
ganil: A kind of brittle limestone. [Prov. Eng.] Kirwan.
grossification: The swelling of the ovary of plants after fertilization.Henslow.
grimace: A distortion of the countenance, whether habitual, fromaffectation, or momentary aad occasional, to express some feeling, ascontempt, disapprobation, complacency, etc.; a smirk; a made-up face.Moving his face into such a hideons grimace, that every feature of itappeared under a different distortion. Addison.
gladiolus: A genus of plants having bulbous roots and gladiate leaves, andincluding many species, some of which are cultivated and valued forthe beauty of their flowers; the corn flag; the sword lily.
gaol: A place of confinement, especially for minor offenses orprovisional imprisonment; a jail. [Preferably, and in the UnitedStates usually, written jail.] Commission of general gaol delivery,an authority conferred upon judges and others included in it, fortrying and delivering every prisoner in jail when the judges, upontheir circuit, arrive at the place for holding court, and fordischarging any whom the grand jury fail to indict. [Eng.] -- Gaoldelivery. (Law) See Jail delivery, under Jail.
gallotannic: Pertaining to the tannin or nutgalls. Gallotannic acid. SeeTannic acid, under Tannic.
geologist: One versed in the science of geology.
ganoidei: One of the subclasses of fishes. They have an arterial cone andbulb, spiral intestinal valve, and the optic nerves united by achiasma. Many of the species are covered with bony plates, or withganoid scales; others have cycloid scales.
gynobasic: Pertaining to, or having, a gynobase.
grandchild: A son's or daughter's child; a child in the second degree ofdescent.
generate: To trace out, as a line, figure, or solid, by the motion of apoint or a magnitude of inferior order.
goliard: A buffoon in the Middle Ages, who attended rich men's tables tomake sport for the guests by ribald stories and songs.
genoa cake: A rich glazed cake, with almonds, pistachios, filberts, orother nuts; also, a rich currant cake with almonds on the top.
grater: One who, or that which, grates; especially, an instrument orutensil with a rough, indented surface, for rubbing off smallparticles of any substance; as a grater for nutmegs.
grantee: The person to whom a grant or conveyance is made.His grace will not survive the poor grantee he despises. Burke.
gopher wood: A species of wood used in the construction of Noah's ark. Gen.vi. 14.
gern: To grin or yawn. [Obs.] "[/He] gaped like a gulf when he didgern." Spenser.
grab: A vessel used on the Malabar coast, having two or three masts.
giftedness: The state of being gifted. Echard.
gid: A disease of sheep, characterized by vertigo; the staggers. Itis caused by the presence of the CC.
gynoecium: The pistils of a flower, taken collectively. See Illust. ofCarpophore.
gastrotomy: A cutting into, or opening of, the abdomen or the stomach.
galapee tree: The West Indian Sciadophyllum Brownei, a tree with very largedigitate leaves.
guicowar: [Mahratta gaekwar, prop., a cowherd.] The title of thesovereign of Guzerat, in Western India; -- generally called theGuicowar of Baroda, which is the capital of the country.
gnomonically: According to the principles of the gnomonic projection.
guildhall: The hall where a guild or corporation usually assembles; atownhall.
gentianose: A crystallizable, sugarlike substance, with a slightly sweetishtaste, obtained from the gentian.
goniometer: An instrument for measuring angles, especially the angles ofcrystals, or the inclination of planes. Contact, or Hand, goniometer,a goniometer having two movable arms (ab, cd), between which (at ab)the faces of the crystals are placed. These arms turn about a fixedpoint, which is the center of the graduated circle or semicircle uponwhich the angle is read off.-- Reflecting goniometer, an instrument for measuring the angles ofcrystals by determining through what angular space the crystal mustbe turned so that two rays reflected from two surfaces successivelyshall have the same direction; -- called also Wollaston's goniometer,from the inventor.
galingale: A plant of the Sedge family (Cyperus longus) having aromaticroots; also, any plant of the same genus. Chaucer.Meadow, set with slender galingale. Tennyson.
george noble: A gold noble of the time of Henry VIII. See Noble, n.
gomphiasis: A disease of the teeth, which causes them to loosen and fallout of their sockets.
gelada: A baboon (Gelada Ruppelli) of Abyssinia, remarkable for thelength of the hair on the neck and shoulders of the adult male.
geniting: A species of apple that ripens very early. Bacon.
glossa: The tongue, or lingua, of an insect. See Hymenoptera.
glandiform: Having the form of a gland or nut; resembling a gland.
goodness: The quality of being good in any of its various senses;excellence; virtue; kindness; benevolence; as, the goodness oftimber, of a soil, of food; goodness of character, of disposition, ofconduct, etc.
grandmother: The mother of one's father or mother.
grog: A mixture of spirit and water not sweetened; hence, anyintoxicating liquor. Grog blossom, a redness on the nose or face ofpersons who drink ardent spirits to excess. [Collog.]
gobbet: A mouthful; a lump; a small piece. Spenser.[He] had broken the stocks to small gobbets. Wyclif.
glyceryl: A compound radical, C3H5, regarded as the essential radical ofglycerin. It is metameric with allyl. Called also propenyl.
gummer: A punch-cutting tool, or machine for deepening and enlargingthe spaces between the teeth of a worn saw.
glyptography: The art or process of engraving on precious stones. [R.]
gelatinous: Of the nature and consistence of gelatin or the jelly;resembling jelly; viscous.
goll: A hand, paw, or claw. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney. B. Jonson.
gendarme: One of a body of heavy cavalry. [Obs.] [France]
greaves: The sediment of melted tallow. It is made into cakes for dogs'food. In Scotland it is called cracklings. [Written also graves.]
ginny-carriage: A small, strong carriage for conveying materials on a railroad.[Eng.]
goby: One of several species of small marine fishes of the genusGobius and allied genera.
graduate: To bring to a certain degree of consistency, by evaporation, asa fluid. Graduating engine, a dividing engine. See Dividing engine,under Dividing.
graystone: A grayish or greenish compact rock, composed of feldspar andaugite, and allied to basalt.
genus: A class of objects divided into several subordinate species; aclass more extensive than a species; a precisely defined and exactlydivided class; one of the five predicable conceptions, or sorts ofterms.
gullible: Easily gulled; that may be duped.-- Gul"li*bii`i*ty, n. Burke.
giambeux: Greaves; armor for the legs. [Obs.] Spenser.
globule: A minute spherical or rounded structure; as blood, lymph, andpus corpuscles, minute fungi, spores, etc.
glyptotheca: A building or room devoted to works of sculpture.
gerlind: A salmon returning from the sea the second time. [Prov. Eng.]
guttifer: A plant that exudes gum or resin.
grower: One who grows or produces; as, a grower of corn; also, thatwhich grows or increases; as, a vine may be a rank or a slow grower.
gain: A square or beveled notch cut out of a girder, binding joist,or other timber which supports a floor beam, so as to receive the endof the floor beam.
grizzly: Somewhat gray; grizzled.Old squirrels that turn grizzly. Bacon.Grizzly bear (Zoöl.), a large and ferocious bear (Ursus horribilis)of Western North America and the Rocky Mountains. It is remarkablefor the great length of its claws.
greenth: The state or quality of being green; verdure. [R.]The greenth of summer. G. Eliot.
gittith: A musical instrument, of unknown character, supposed by some tohave been used by the people of Gath, and thence obtained by David.It is mentioned in the title of Psalms viii., lxxxi., and lxxxiv. Dr.W. Smith.
geophagism: The act or habit of eating earth. See Dirt eating, under Dirt.Dunglison.
gravel-stone: A pebble, or small fragment of stone; a calculus.
glutinative: Having the quality of cementing; tenacious; viscous; glutinous.
gregal: Pertaining to, or like, a flock.For this gregal conformity there is an excuse. W. S. Mayo.
glout: To pout; to look sullen. [Obs.] Garth.
grapeshot: A cluster, usually nine in number, of small iron balls, puttogether by means of cast-iron circular plates at top and bottom,with two rings, and a central connecting rod, in order to be used asa charge for a cannon. Formerly grapeshot were inclosed in canvasbags.
gaur: An East Indian species of wild cattle (Bibos gauris), of largesize and an untamable disposition. [Spelt also gour.]
gutturalism: The quality of being guttural; as, the gutturalism of A [in the16th cent.] Earle.
guidance: The act or result of guiding; the superintendence or assistanceof a guide; direction; government; a leading.His studies were without guidance and without plan. Macaulay.
gibfish: The male of the salmon. [Prov. Eng.] Wright.
graticule: A design or draught which has been divided into squares, inorder to reproduce it in other dimensions.
grindle: The bowfin; -- called also Johnny Grindle. [Local, U. S.]
gamma: The third letter (G) of the Greek alphabet.
guano: A substance found in great abundance on some coasts or islandsfrequented by sea fowls, and composed chiefly of their excrement. Itis rich in phosphates and ammonia, and is used as a powerfulfertilizer.
guarded: Cautious; wary; circumspect; as, he was guarded in hisexpressions; framed or uttered with caution; as, his expressions wereguarded.-- Guard"edly, adv.-- Guard"ed*ness, n.
glean: A collection made by gleaning.The gleans of yellow thyme distend his thighs. Dryden.
geissler tube: A glass tube provided with platinum electrodes, and containingsome gas under very low tension, which becomes luminous when anelectrical discharge is passed through it; -- so called from the nameof a noted maker in germany. It is called also Plücker tube, from theGerman physicist who devised it.
ghostfish: A pale ubspotted variety of the wrymouth.
gymnochroa: A division of Hydroidea including the hydra. See Hydra.
gnide: To rub; to bruise; to break in pieces. [Obs.]
garrot: A stick or small wooden cylinder used for tightening a bandage,in order to compress the arteries of a limb.
glyoxime: A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance, produced by theaction of hydroxylamine on glyoxal, and belonging to the class ofoximes; also, any one of a group of substances resembling glyoximeproper, and of which it is a type. See Oxime.
glucic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, sugar; as, glucic acid.
gradualness: The quality or state of being gradual; regular progression orgradation; slowness.The gradualness of this movement. M. Arnold.The gradualness of growth is a characteristic which strikes thesimplest observer. H. Drummond.
gothicize: To make Gothic; to bring back to barbarism.
gimcrack: A trivial mechanism; a device; a toy; a pretty thing.Arbuthnot.
genitival: Possessing genitive from; pertaining to, or derived from, thegenitive case; as, a genitival adverb.-- Gen`i*ti"val*ly, adv.
goldylocks: A plant of several species of the genus Chrysocoma; -- socalled from the tufts of yellow flowers which terminate the stems;also, the Ranunculus auricomus, a kind of buttercup.
gambadoes: Same as Gamashes.His thin legs tenanted a pair of gambadoes fastened at the side withrusty clasps. Sir W. Scott.
giver: One who gives; a donor; a bestower; a grantor; one who impartsor distributes.It is the giver, and not the gift, that engrosses the heart of theChristian. Kollock.
gadoid: Of or pertaining to the family of fishes (Gadidæ) whichincludes the cod, haddock, and hake.-- n.
gelsemine: An alkaloid obtained from the yellow jasmine (Gelsemiumsempervirens), as a bitter white semicrystalline substance; -- calledalso gelsemia.
grisaille: Decorative painting in gray monochrome; -- used in Englishespecially for painted glass.
grahamite: One who follows the dietetic system of Graham. [U. S.]
groundwork: That which forms the foundation or support of anything; thebasis; the essential or fundamental part; first principle. Dryden.
guest: To receive or entertain hospitably. [Obs.] Sylvester.
gobbler: A turkey cock; a bubbling Jock.
greenroom: The retiring room of actors and actresses in a theater.
gainless: Not producing gain; unprofitable. Hammond.-- Gain"less/ness, n.
group: A variously limited assemblage of animals or planta, havingsome resemblance, or common characteristics in form or structure. Theterm has different uses, and may be made to include certain speciesof a genus, or a whole genus, or certain genera, or even severalorders.
gastromalacia: A softening of the coats of the stomach; -- usually a post-morten change.
gabbro: A name originally given by the Italians to a kind ofserpentine, later to the rock called euphotide, and now generallyused for a coarsely crystalline, igneous rock consisting of lamellarpyroxene (diallage) and labradorite, with sometimes chrysolite(olivine gabbro).
glioma: A tumor springing from the neuroglia or connective tissue ofthe brain, spinal cord, or other portions of the nervous system.
gama grass: A species of grass (Tripsacum dactyloides) tall, stout, andexceedingly productive; cultivated in the West Indies, Mexico, andthe Southern States of North America as a forage grass; -- calledalso sesame grass.
gruf: Forwards; with one's face to the ground. [Obs.]They fellen gruf, and cryed piteously. Chaucer.
groomsman: A male attendant of a bridegroom at his wedding; -- thecorrelative of bridesmaid.
governess: A female governor; a woman invested with authority to controland direct; especially, one intrusted with the care and instructionof children, -- usually in their homes.
germination: The process of germinating; the beginning of vegetation orgrowth in a seed or plant; the first development of germs, eitheranimal or vegetable. Germination apparatus, an apparatus for maltinggrain.
goa powder: A bitter powder (also called araroba) found in the interspacesof the wood of a Brazilian tree (Andira araroba) and used as amedicine. It is the material from which chrysarobin is obtained.
garter: Same as Bendlet. Garter fish (Zoöl.), a fish of the genusLepidopus, having a long, flat body, like the blade of a sword; thescabbard fish.-- Garter king-at-arms, the chief of the official heralds ofEngland, king-at-arms to the Order of the Garter; -- oftenabbreviated to Garter.-- Garter snake (Zoöl.), one of several harmless American snakes ofthe genus Eutænia, of several species (esp. E. saurita and E.sirtalis); one of the striped snakes; -- so called from itsconspicuous stripes of color.
give: To set forth as a known quantity or a known relation, or as apremise from which to reason; -- used principally in the passive formgiven.
gith: The corn cockle; also anciently applied to the Nigella, orfennel flower.
glance: A name given to some sulphides, mostly dark-colored, which havea brilliant metallic luster, as the sulphide of copper, called copperglance. Glance coal, anthracite; a mineral composed chiefly ofcarbon.-- Glance cobalt, cobaltite, or gray cobalt.-- Glance copper, c -- Glance wood, a hard wood grown in Cuba, andused for gauging instruments, carpenters' rules, etc. McElrath.
guest rope: The line by which a boat makes fast to the swinging boom. Ham.Nav. Encyc.
gemul: A small South American deer (Furcifer Chilensis), with simpleforked horns. [Written also guemul.]
guilt-sick: Made sick by consciousness of guilt. "A guilt-sick conscience."Beau. c& El.
gar: To cause; to make. [Obs. or Scot.] Spenser.
gripingly: In a griping or oppressive manner. Bacon.
gadolinia: A rare earth, regarded by some as an oxide of the supposedelement gadolinium, by others as only a mixture of the oxides ofyttrium, erbium, ytterbium, etc.
ground: A floor or pavement supposed to rest upon the earth.
gesticulatory: Representing by, or belonging to, gestures. T. Warton.
grapsoid: Pertaining to the genus Grapsus or the family Grapsidæ.-- n.
guanaco: A South American mammal (Auchenia huanaco), allied to thellama, but of larger size and more graceful form, inhabiting thesouthern Andes and Patagonia. It is supposed by some to be the llamain a wild state. [Written also huanaco.]
graphotype: A process for producing a design upon a surface in relief sothat it can be printed from. Prepared chalk or oxide of zinc ispressed upon a smooth plate by a hydraulic press, and the design isdrawn upon this in a peculiar ink which hardens the surface whereverit is applied. The surface is then carefully rubbed or brushed,leaving the lines in relief.
generalizer: One who takes general or comprehensive views. Tyndall.
gunboat: A vessel of light draught, carrying one or more guns.
gamble: To play or game for money or other stake.
grubworm: See Grub, n., 1.And gnats and grubworms crowded on his view. C. Smart.
gnu: One of two species of large South African antelopes of thegenus Catoblephas, having a mane and bushy tail, and curved horns inboth sexes. [Written also gnoo.]
gentiopikrin: A bitter, yellow, crystalline substance, regarded as aglucoside, and obtained from the gentian.
gradient: Any member like a step, as the raised back of an altar or thelike; a set raised over another. "The gradines of the amphitheeater."Layard.
grace: The divine favor toward man; the mercy of God, as distinguishedfrom His justice; also, any benefits His mercy imparts; divine loveor pardon; a state of acceptance with God; enjoyment of the divinefavor.And if by grace, then is it no more of works. Rom. xi. 6.My grace is sufficicnt for thee. 2 Cor. xii. 9.Where sin abounded, grace did much more abound. Rom. v. 20.By whom also we have access by faith into this grace wherein westand. Rom. v.2
gynecology: The science which treats of the structure and diseases ofwomen.-- Gyn`e*col"o*gist.
geniculate: Bent abruptly at an angle, like the knee when bent; as, ageniculate stem; a geniculate ganglion; a geniculate twin crystal.
gimmal: Made or consisting of interlocked rings, gimmal mail.In their pale dull mouths the gimmal bit Lies foul with chewed grass.Shak.Gimmal joint. See Gimbal joint, under Gimbal.
godfather: A man who becomes sponsor for a child at baptism, and makeshimself a surety for its Christian training and instruction.There shall be for every Male-child to be baptized, when they can behad, two Godfathers and one Godmother; and for every Female, oneGodfather and two Godmothers; and Parents shall be admitted asSponsors, if it is desired. Book of Common Prayer (Prot. Episc. Ch.,U. S. ).
gemitores: A division of birds including the true pigeons.
gutturalize: To speak gutturally; to give a guttural sound to.
gamp: A large umbrella; --said to allude to Mrs. Gamp's umbrella, inDickens's "Martin Chuzzlewit."
gentlemanship: The carriage or quality of a gentleman.
gruff: Of a rough or stern manner, voice, or countenance; sour; surly;severe; harsh. Addison.Gruff, disagreeable, sarcastic remarks. Thackeray.-- Gruff"ly, adv.-- Gruff"ness, n.
gallivant: To play the beau; to wait upon the ladies; also, to roam aboutfor pleasure without any definite plan. [Slang] Dickens.
geodesy: That branch of applied mathematics which determines, by meansof observations and measurements, the figures and areas of largeportions of the earth's surface, or the general figure anddimenshions of the earth; or that branch of surveying in which thecurvature of the earth is taken into account, as in the surveys ofStates, or of long lines of coast.
gymnotus: A genus of South American fresh-water fishes, including theGymnotus electricus, or electric eel. It has a greenish, eel-likebody, and is possessed of electric power.One fearful shock, fearful but momentary, like from the electric blowof the gymnotus. De Quincey.
greasy: Affected with the disease called grease; as, the heels of ahorse. See Grease, n., 2.
gymnoplast: A cell or mass of protoplasm devoid of an envelope, as a whiteblood corpuscle.
glover: One whose trade it is to make or sell gloves. Glover's sutureor stitch, a kind of stitch used in sewing up wounds, in which thethread is drawn alternately through each side from within outward.
gephyrea: An order of marine Annelida, in which the body is imperfectly,or not at all, annulated externally, and is mostly without setæ.
ghawazi: Egyptian dancing girls, of a lower sort than the almeh.
good: Wares; commodities; chattels; -- formerly used in the singularin a collective sense. In law, a comprehensive name for almost allpersonal property as distinguished from land or real property.Wharton.He hath made us spend much good. Chaucer.Thy lands and goods Are, by the laws of Venice, confiscate Unto thestate of Venice. Shak.Dress goods, Dry goods, etc. See in the Vocabulary.-- Goods engine, a freight locomotive. [Eng.] -- Goods train, afreight train. [Eng.] -- Goods wagon, a freight car [Eng.] See theNote under Car, n., 2.
galericulate: Covered as with a hat or cap. Smart.
gastrophrenic: Pertaining to the stomach and diaphragm; as, the gastrophrenicligament.
germarium: An organ in which the ova are developed in certain Turbellaria.
gargil: A distemper in geese, affecting the head.
glandage: A feeding on nuts or mast. [Obs.] Crabb.
gryllus: A genus of insects including the common crickets.
gastroelytrotomy: The operation of cutting into the upper part of the vagina,through the abdomen (without opening the peritoneum), for the purposeof removing a fetus. It is a substitute for the Cæsarean operation,and less dangerous.
gobioid: Like, or pertaining to, the goby, or the genus Gobius.-- n.
genethliac: Pertaining to nativities; calculated by astrologers; showingposition of stars at one's birth. Howell.
gerundial: Pertaining to, or resembling, a gerund; as, a gerundial use.
geanticlinal: An upward bend or flexure of a considerable portion of theearth's crust, resulting in the formation of a class of mountainelevations called anticlinoria; -- opposed to geosynclinal.
gumma: A kind of soft tumor, usually of syphilitic origin.
genipap: The edible fruit of a West Indian tree (Genipa Americana) ofthe order Rubiaceæ. It is oval in shape, as a large as a smallorange, of a pale greenish color, and with dark purple juice.
grained: Having tubercles or grainlike processes, as the petals orsepals of some flowers.
gasoscope: An apparatus for detecting the presence of any dangerous gas,from a gas leak in a coal mine or a dwelling house.
gymnosomata: One of the orders of Pteropoda. They have no shell.
glasswort: A seashore plant of the Spinach family (Salicornia herbacea),with succulent jointed stems; also, a prickly plant of the samefamily (Salsola Kali), both formerly burned for the sake of theashes, which yield soda for making glass and soap.
gourd tree: A tree (the Crescentia Cujete, or calabash tree) of the WestIndies and Central America.
greenish: Somewhat green; having a tinge of green; as, a greenish yellow.-- Green"ish*ness, n.
ghost: To die; to expire. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
grapy: Composed of, or resembling, grapes.The grapy clusters. Addison.
godliness: Careful observance of, or conformity to, the laws of God; thestate or quality of being godly; piety.Godliness is profitable unto all things. 1 Tim. iv. 8.
geic: Pertaining to, or derived from, earthy or vegetable mold. Geicacid. (Chem.) See Humin.
gimlet: A small tool for boring holes. It has a leading screw, agrooved body, and a cross handle. Gimlet eye, a squint-eye. [Colloq.]Wright.
gouache: A method of painting with opaque colors, which have been groundin water and mingled with a preparation of gum; also, a picture thuspainted.
gyp: A college servant; -- so called in Cambridge, England; atOxford called a scout. [Cant]
griper: One who gripes; an oppressor; an extortioner. Burton.
greffier: A registrar or recorder; a notary. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
going: Course of life; behavior; doings; ways.His eyes are upon the ways of man, and he seeth all his goings. Jobxxxiv. 21.Going barrel. (Horology) (a) A barrel containing the mainspring, andhaving teeth on its periphery to drive the train. (b) A device formaintaining a force to drive the train while the timepiece is beingwound up.-- Going forth. (Script.) (a) Outlet; way of exit. "Every goingforth of the sanctuary." Ezek. xliv. 5. (b) A limit; a border. "Thegoing forth thereof shall be from the south to Kadesh-barnea." Num.xxxiv. 4.-- Going out, or Goings out. (Script.) (a) The utmost extremity orlimit. "The border shall go down to Jordan, and the goings out of itshall be at the salt sea." Num. xxxiv. 12. (b) Departure orjourneying. "And Moses wrote their goings out according to theirjourneys." Num. xxxiii. 2.-- Goings on, behavior; actions; conduct; -- usually in a bad sense.
gley: To squint; to look obliquely; to overlook things. [Scot.]Jamieson.
goody-goody: Mawkishly or weakly good; exhibiting goodness with silliness.[Colloq.]
getterup: One who contrives, makes, or arranges for, anything, as a book,a machine, etc. [Colloq.]A diligent getter-up of miscellaneous works. W. Irving.
giddiness: The quality or state of being giddy.
gravamen: The grievance complained of; the substantial cause of theaction; also, in general, the ground or essence of a complaint.Bouvier.
grallae: An order of birds which formerly included all the waders. Bylater writers it is usually restricted to the sandpipers, plovers,and allied forms; -- called also Grallatores.
gowd: Gold; wealth. [Scot.]The man's the gowd for a' that. Burns.
gastronomy: The art or science of good eating; epicurism; the art of goodcheer.
girdler: An American longicorn beetle (Oncideres cingulatus) which laysits eggs in the twigs of the hickory, and then girdles each branch bygnawing a groove around it, thus killing it to provide suitable foodfor the larvæ.
garland: To deck with a garland. B. Jonson.
gastromyces: The fungoid growths sometimes found in the stomach; such asTorula, etc.
glycosometer: An apparatus for determining the amount of sugar in diabeticurine.
granulose: The main constituent of the starch grain or granule, indistinction from the framework of cellulose. Unlike cellulose, it iscolored blue by iodine, and is converted into dextrin and sugar byboiling acids and amylolytic ferments.
gleam: To disgorge filth, as a hawk.
gladius: The internal shell, or pen, of cephalopods like the squids.
goa: A species of antelope (Procapra picticauda), inhabiting Thibet.
garbage: Offal, as the bowels of an animal or fish; refuse animal orvegetable matter from a kitchen; hence, anything worthless,disgusting, or loathsome. Grainger.
gregarious: Habitually living or moving in flocks or herds; tending toflock or herd together; not habitually solitary or living alone.Burke.No birds of prey are gregarious. Ray.-- Gre*ga"ri*ous*ly, adv.-- Gre-ga'ri-ous-ness, n.
gastrodisc: That part of blastoderm where the hypoblast appears like asmall disk on the inner face of the epibladst.
gourdworm: The fluke of sheep. See Fluke.
germinal: Pertaining or belonging to a germ; as, the germinal vesicle.Germinal layers (Biol.), the two layers of cells, the ectoblast andentoblast, which form respectively the outer covering and inner wallof the gastrula. A third layer of cells, the mesoblast, which isformed later and lies between these two, is sometimes included.-- Germinal membrane. (Biol.) Same as Blastoderm.-- Germinal spot (Biol.), the nucleolus of the ovum.-- Germinal vesicle, (Biol.) , the nucleus of the ovum of animals.
gloze: To smooth over; to palliate.By glozing the evil that is in the world. I. Taylor.
gnomon: The style or pin, which by its shadow, shows the hour of theday. It is usually set parallel to the earth's axis.
gamophyllous: Composed of leaves united by their edges (coalescent). Gray.
gross: The number of twelve dozen; twelve times twelve; as, a gross ofbottles; ten gross of pens. Advowson in gross (Law), an advowsonbelonging to a person, and not to a manor.-- A great gross, twelve gross; one hundred and forty-four dozen.-- By the gross, by the quantity; at wholesale.-- Common in gross. (Law) See under Common, n.-- In the gross, In gross, in the bulk, or the undivided whole; allparts taken together.
great: The whole.; the gross; as, a contract to build a ship by thegreat.
gallon: A measure of capacity, containing four quarts; -- used, for themost part, in liquid measure, but sometimes in dry measure.
gyracanthus: A genus of fossil fishes, found in Devonian and carboniferousstrata; -- so named from their round, sculptured spines.
guard: To watch by way of caution or defense; to be caution; to be ina state or position of defense or safety; as, careful persons guardagainst mistakes.
gusto: Nice or keen appreciation or enjoyment; relish; taste; fancy.Dryden.
gule: To give the color of gules to.
gaviae: The division of birds which includes the gulls and terns.
glanders: A highly contagious and very destructive disease of horses,asses, mules, etc., characterized by a constant discharge of stickymatter from the nose, and an enlargement and induration of the glandsbeneath and within the lower jaw. It may transmitted to dogs, goats,sheep, and to human beings.
gaelic: Of or pertaining to the Gael, esp. to the Celtic Highlanders ofScotland; as, the Gaelic language.
guerdonable: Worthy of reward. Sir G. Buck.
glyconic: Consisting of a spondee, a choriamb, and a pyrrhic; -- appliedto a kind of verse in Greek and Latin poetry.-- n. (Pros.)
guarana: A preparation from the seeds of Paullinia sorbilis, a woodyclimber of Brazil, used in making an astringent drink, and also inthe cure of headache.
gemmification: The production of a bud or gem.
gaekwar: The title of the ruling Prince of Baroda, in Gujarat, inBombay, India.
gnathostoma: A comprehensive division of vertebrates, including all thathave distinct jaws, in contrast with the leptocardians andmarsipobranchs (Cyclostoma), which lack them. [Written alsoGnathostomata.]
geographically: In a geographical manner or method; according to geography.
gunsmith: One whose occupation is to make or repair small firearms; anarmorer.
gallicize: To conform to the French mode or idiom.
geomalism: The tendency of an organism to respond, during its growth, tothe force of gravitation.
gemmosity: The quality or characteristics of a gem or jewel. [Obs.]Bailey.
gabarage: A kind of coarse cloth for packing goods. [Obs.]
girth: To bind as with a girth. [R.] Johnson.
gelatigenous: Producing, or yielding, gelatin; gelatiniferous; as, thegelatigeneous tissues.
golden-rod: A tall herb (Solidago Virga-aurea), bearing yellow flowers in agraceful elongated cluster. The name is common to all the species ofthe genus Solidago. Golden-rod tree (Bot.), a shrub (BoseaYervamora), a native of the Canary Isles.
gastrula: An embryonic form having its origin in the invagination orpushing in of the wall of the planula or blastula (the blastosphere)on one side, thus giving rise to a double-walled sac, with oneopening or mouth (the blastopore) which leads into the cavity (thearchenteron) lined by the inner wall (the hypoblast). See Illust.under Invagination. In a more general sense, an ideal stage inembryonic development. See Gastræa.-- a.
galvanoscope: An instrument or apparatus for detecting the presence ofelectrical currents, especially such as are of feeble intensity.
gaylussite: A yellowish white, translucent mineral, consisting of thecarbonates of lime and soda, with water.
grunt: To make a deep, short noise, as a hog; to utter a short groanor a deep guttural sound.Who would fardels bear, To grunt and sweat under a weary life. Shak.Grunting ox (Zoöl.), the yak.
gynandromorphism: An abnormal condition of certain animals, in which one side hasthe external characters of the male, and the other those of thefemale.
granolithic: A kind of hard artificial stone, used for pavements.
galvanoscopy: The use of galvanism in physiological experiments.
gravity: The tendency of a mass of matter toward a center of attraction;esp., the tendency of a body toward the center of the earth;terrestrial gravitation.
greenlet: l. (Zoöl.) One of numerous species of small American singingbirds, of the genus Vireo, as the solitary, or blue-headed (Vireosolitarius); the brotherly-love (V. Philadelphicus); the warblinggreenlet (V. gilvus); the yellow-throated greenlet (V. flavifrons)and others. See Vireo.
gordius: A genus of long, slender, nematoid worms, parasitic in insectsuntil near maturity, when they leave the insect, and live in water,in which they deposit their eggs; -- called also hair eel, hairworm,and hair snake, from the absurd, but common and widely diffused,notion that they are metamorphosed horsehairs.
grangerite: One who collects illustrations from various books for thedecoration of one book.
glister: To be bright; to sparkle; to be brilliant; to shine; toglisten; to glitter.All that glisters is not gold. Shak.
gnaphalium: A genus of composite plants with white or colored dry andpersistent involucres; a kind of everlasting.
graffage: The scarp of a ditch or moat. "To clean the graffages." MissMitford.
germanization: The act of Germanizing. M. Arnold.
grecism: An idiom of the Greek language; a Hellenism. Addison.
geitonogamy: Fertilization of flowers by pollen from other flowers on thesame plant.
goosefoot: A genus of herbs (Chenopodium) mostly annual weeds; pigweed.
gastornis: A genus of large eocene birds from the Paris basin.
garcinia: A genus of plants, including the mangosteen tree (GarciniaMangostana), found in the islands of the Indian Archipelago; -- socalled in honor of Dr. Garcin.
guardianess: A female guardian.I have placed a trusty, watchful guardianess. Beau. & Fl.
gnome: A small owl (Glaucidium gnoma) of the Western United States.
guardable: Capable of being guarded or protected.
gyte: Delirious; senselessly extravagant; as, the man is clean gyte.[Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
glumly: In a glum manner; sullenly; moodily.
galvanoplasty: The art or process of electrotypy.
gord: An instrument of gaming; a sort of dice. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
galliwasp: A West Indian lizard (Celestus occiduus), about a foot long,imagined by the natives to be venomous.
generator: The principal sound or sounds by which others are produced; thefundamental note or root of the common chord; -- called alsogenerating tone.
generically: With regard to a genus, or an extensive class; as, an animalgenerically distinct from another, or two animals or plantsgenerically allied.
goldfinny: One of two or more species of European labroid fishes(Crenilabrus melops, and Ctenolabrus rupestris); -- called alsogoldsinny, and goldney.
growse: To shiver; to have chills. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Ray.
gastropoda: One of the classes of Mollusca, of great extent. It includesmost of the marine spiral shells, and the land and fresh-watersnails. They generally creep by means of a flat, muscular disk, orfoot, on the ventral side of the body. The head usually bears one ortwo pairs of tentacles. See Mollusca. [Written also Gasteropoda.]
gardener: One who makes and tends a garden; a horticulturist.
gassing: The process of passing cotton goods between two rollers andexposing them to numerous minute jets of gas to burn off the smallfibers; any similar process of singeing.
gee: To turn to the off side, or from the driver (i.e., in theUnited States, to the right side); -- said of cattle, or a team; usedmost frequently in the imperative, often with off, by drivers ofoxen, in directing their teams, and opposed to haw, or hoi. [Writtenalso jee.]
geminous: Double; in pairs. Sir T. Browne.
gentle: A dipterous larva used as fish bait.
gubernation: The act of governing; government [Obs.] I. Watts.
griseous: Of a light color, or white, mottled with black or brown;grizzled or grizzly. Maunder.
grenadillo: A handsome tropical American wood, much used for making flutesand other wind instruments; -- called also Grenada cocos, or cocus,and red ebony.
gerocomical: Pertaining to gerocomy. Dr. John Smith.
galvanocautery: Cautery effected by a knife or needle heated by the passage ofa galvanic current.
gauffer: To plait, crimp, or flute; to goffer, as lace. See Goffer.
gluttonize: To eat to excess; to eat voraciously; to gormandize. Hallywell.
gainful: Profitable; advantageous; lucrative. "A gainful speculation."Macaulay.-- Gain"ful*ly, adv.-- Gain"ful*ness, n.
gyrostat: A modification of the gyroscope, consisting essentially of afly wheel fixed inside a rigid case to which is attached a thinflange of metal for supporting the instrument. It is used in studyingthe dynamics of rotating bodies.
gerrymander: To divide (a State) into districts for the choice ofrepresentatives, in an unnatural and unfair way, with a view to givea political party an advantage over its opponent. [Political Cant, U.S.]
gasserian: Relating to Casserio (L. Gasserius), the discover of theGasserian ganglion. Gasserian ganglion (Anat.), a large ganglion, atthe root of the trigeminal, or fifth cranial, nerve.
glacialist: One who attributes the phenomena of the drift, in geology, toglaciers.
germ: That which is to develop a new individual; as, the germ of afetus, of a plant or flower, and the like; the earliest form underwhich an organism appears.In the entire process in which a new being originates . . . twodistinct classes of action participate; namely, the act of generationby which the germ is produced; and the act of development, by whichthat germ is evolved into the complete organism. Carpenter.
grade: The result of crossing a native stock with some better breed.If the crossbreed have more than three fourths of the better blood,it is called high grade. At grade, on the same level; -- said of thecrossing of a railroad with another railroad or a highway, when theyare on the same level at the point of crossing.-- Down grade, a descent, as on a graded railroad.-- Up grade, an ascent, as on a graded railroad.-- Equating for grades. See under Equate.-- Grade crossing, a crossing at grade.
gymnocytode: A cytode without either a cell wall or a nucleus. Haeckel.
glastonbury thorn: A variety of the common hawthorn. Loudon.
glycidic: Pertaining to, or derived from, glycide; as, glycidic acid.
gurlet: A pickax with one sharp point and one cutting edge. Knight.
gentianella: A kind of blue color. Johnson.
graywacke: A conglomerate or grit rock, consisting of rounded pebbles sandfirmly united together.
grub: The larva of an insect, especially of a beetle; -- called alsogrubworm. See Illust. of Goldsmith beetle, under Goldsmith.Yet your butterfly was a grub. Shak.
gutturo-: A combining form denoting relation to the throat; as, gutturo-nasal, having both a guttural and a nasal character; gutturo-palatal.
godless: Having, or acknowledging, no God; without reverence for God;impious; wicked.-- God"less*ly, adv.-- God"less*ness, n.
gristly: Consisting of, or containing, gristle; like gristle;cartilaginous.
gelseminic: Pertaining to, or derived from, the yellow jasmine (Gelsemiumsempervirens); as, gelseminic acid, a white crystalline substanceresembling esculin.
galvanoscopic: Of or pertaining to a galvanoscope.
granule: A little grain a small particle; a pellet.
guna: In Sanskrit grammar, a lengthening of the simple vowels a, i,e, by prefixing an a element. The term is sometimes used to denotethe same vowel change in other languages.
glyptographic: Relating to glyptography, or the art of engraving on preciousstones. [R.]
godspeed: Success; prosperous journeying; -- a contraction of the phrase,"God speed you." [Written also as two separate words.]Receive him not into house, neither bid him God speed. 2 John 10.
gorcrow: The carrion crow; -- called also gercrow. [Prov. Eng.]
geogony: The branch of science which treats of the formation of theearth.
glace: Coated with icing; iced; glazed; -- said of fruits, sweetmeats,cake, etc.
glandered: Affected with glanders; as, a glandered horse. Yu
grandaunt: The aunt of one's father or mother.
glandule: A small gland or secreting vessel.
gaud: To sport or keep festival. [Obs.] "Gauding with his familiars." [Obs.] Sir T. North.
glanderous: Of or pertaining to glanders; of the nature of glanders.Youatt.
groom: To tend or care for, or to curry or clean, as a, horse.
grosgrain: Of a coarse texture; -- applied to silk with a heavy threadrunning crosswise.
grammalogue: Literally, a letter word; a word represented by a logogram; as,it, represented by |, that is, t. pitman.
germane: Literally, near akin; hence, closely allied; appropriate orfitting; relevant.The phrase would be more germane to the matter. Shak.[An amendment] must be germane. Barclay (Digest).
gorgoniacea: One of the principal divisions of Alcyonaria, including thoseforms which have a firm and usually branched axis, covered with aporous crust, or c
genoese: Of or pertaining to Genoa, a city of Italy.-- n. sing. & pl.
gullery: An act, or the practice, of gulling; trickery; fraud. [R.] "Amere gullery." Selden.
girlhood: State or time of being a girl.
gasp: To emit or utter with gasps; -- with forth, out, away, etc.And with short sobs he gasps away his breath. Dryden.
gaussage: The intensity of a magnetic field expressed in C.G.S. units, orgausses.
gout: A constitutional disease, occurring by paroxysms. It constistsin an inflammation of the fibrous and ligamentous parts of thejoints, and almost always attacks first the great toe, next thesmaller joints, after which, it may attack the greater articulations.It is attended with various sympathettic phenomena, particularly inthe digestive organs. It may also attack internal organs, as thestomach, the intestines, etc. Dunglison.
geyser: A boiling spring which throws forth at frequent intervals jetsof water, mud, etc., driven up by the expansive power of steam.
gunroom: An apartment on the after end of the lower gun deck of a shipof war, usually occupied as a messroom by the commissioned officers,except the captain; -- called wardroom in the United States navy.
golgotha: Calvary. See the Note under Calvary.
gargoulette: A water cooler or jug with a handle and spout; a gurglet.Mollett.
gastrulation: The process of invagination, in embryonic development, by whicha gastrula is formed.
gynodioecious: Dioecious, but having some hermaphrodite or perfect flowers onan individual plant which bears mostly pistillate flowers.
gabel: A rent, service, tribute, custom, tax, impost, or duty; anexcise. Burrill.He enables St. Peter to pay his gabel by the ministry of a fish. Jer.Taylor.
giusto: In just, correct, or suitable time.
giblet: Made of giblets; as, a giblet pie.
gyrodus: A genus of extinct oölitic fishes, having rounded teeth inseveral rows adapted for crushing.
goral: An Indian goat antelope (Nemorhedus goral), resembling thechamois.
gentleman: One who bears arms, but has no title.
guaiac: Pertaining to, or resembling, guaiacum.-- n. Guaiacum.
glasshouse: A house where glass is made; a commercial house that deals inglassware.
gauffre: A gopher, esp. the pocket gopher.
greeter: One who greets or salutes another.
glottology: The science of tongues or languages; comparative philology;glossology.
garookuh: A small fishing vessel met with in the Persian Gulf.
gare: Coarse wool on the legs of sheep. Blount.
gigget: Same as Gigot.Cut the slaves to giggets. Beau. & Fl.
gossan: Decomposed rock, usually reddish or ferruginous (owing tooxidized pyrites), forming the upper part of a metallic vein.
gummosity: Gumminess; a viscous or adhesive quality or nature. [R.]Floyer.
gallicanism: The principles, tendencies, or action of those, within theRoman Catholic Church in France, who (esp. in 1682) sought torestrict the papal authority in that country and increase the powerof the national church. Schaff-Herzog Encyc.
grysbok: A small South African antelope (Neotragus melanotis). It isspeckled with gray and chestnut, above; the under parts are reddishfawn.
greenhorn: A raw, inexperienced person; one easily imposed upon. W.Irving.
grudgingness: The state or quality of grudging, or of being full of grudge orunwillingness.
gaming: The act or practice of playing games for stakes or wagers;gambling.
gravitate: To obey the law of gravitation; to exert a force Or pressure,or tend to move, under the influence of gravitation; to tend in anydirection or toward any object.Why does this apple fall to the ground Because all bodies gravitatetoward each other. Sir W. Hamilton.Politicians who naturally gravitate towards the stronger party.Macaulay.
gunning: The act or practice of hunting or shooting game with a gun.The art of gunning was but little practiced. Goldsmith.
galactophorous: Milk-carrying; lactiferous; -- applied to the ducts of mammaryglands.
gazingstock: A person or thing gazed at with scorn or abhorrence; an objectof curiosity or contempt. Bp. Hall.
georgic: A rural poem; a poetical composition on husbandry, containingrules for cultivating lands, etc.; as, the Georgics of Virgil.
gas engine: A kind of internal-combustion engine (which see) using fixedgas; also, broadly, any internal-combustion engine.
gonocalyx: The bell of a sessile gonozooid.
glomerous: Gathered or formed into a ball or round mass. [Obs.] Blount.
gabion: A hollow cylinder of wickerwork, like a basket without abottom. Gabions are made of various sizes, and filled with earth inbuilding fieldworks to shelter men from an enemy's fire.
georgium sidus: The planet Uranus, so named by its discoverer, Sir W. Herschel.
glow: To make hot; to flush. [Poetic]Fans, whose wind did seem To glow the delicate cheeks which they didcool. Shak.
gobemouche: Literally, a fly swallower; hence, once who keeps his mouthopen; a boor; a silly and credulous person.
guide rope: A rope hung from a balloon or dirigible so as trail along theground for about half its length, used to preserve altitudeautomatically, by variation of the length dragging on the ground,without loss of ballast or gas.
gyle: Fermented wort used for making vinegar. Gyle tan (Brewing), alarge vat in which wort ferments.
gavot: A kind of difficult dance; a dance tune, the air of which hastwo brisk and lively, yet dignified, strains in common time, eachplayed twice over. [Written also gavotte.]
glitter: A bright, sparkling light; brilliant and showy luster;brilliancy; as, the glitter of arms; the glitter of royal equipage.Milton.
guttate: Spotted, as if discolored by drops.
galvanizer: One who, or that which, galvanize.
guillemot: One of several northern sea birds, allied to the auks. Theyhave short legs, placed far back, and are expert divers and swimmers.
grucche: To murmur; to grumble. [Obs.]What aileth you, thus for grucche and groan. Chaucer.
grammaticism: A point or principle of grammar. Abp. Leighton.
guimpe: A kind of short chemisette, worn with a low-necked dress.
gardening: The art of occupation of laying out and cultivating gardens;horticulture.
gorgonian: Pertaining to the Gorgoniacea; as, gorgonian coral.
gallant: Polite and attentive to ladies; courteous to women; chivalrous.
glutaric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid so called; as,glutaric ethers. Glutaric acid, an organic acid obtained as a whitecrystalline substance, isomeric with pyrotartaric acid; -- calledalso normal pyrotartaric acid.
gastroduodenal: Pertaining to the stomach and duodenum; as, the gastroduodenalartery.
generatrix: That which generates; the point, or the mathematical magnitude,which, by its motion, generates another magnitude, as a line,surface, or solid; -- called also describent.
goad: A pointed instrument used to urge on a beast; hence, anynecessity that urges or stimulates.The daily goad urging him to the daily toil. Macaulay.
gravitative: Causing to gravitate; tending to a center. Coleridge.
gemini: A constellation of the zodiac, containing the two bright starsCastor and Pollux; also, the third sign of the zodiac, which the sunenters about May 20th.
gramashes: Gaiters reaching to the knee; leggings.Strong gramashes, or leggings of thick gray cloth. Sir W. Scott.
grubby: Dirty; unclean. [Colloq.]The grubby game of marbles. Lond. Sat. Rev.
gastropodous: Of or pertaining to the Gastropoda.
gaverick: The European red gurnard (Trigla cuculus). [Prov. Eng.]
glass-snail: A small, transparent, land snail, of the genus Vitrina.
geochemistry: The study of the chemical composition of, and of actual orpossible chemical changes in, the crust of the earth. --Ge`o*chem"ic*al (#), a. --Ge`o*chem"ist (#), n.
gloriosa: A genus of climbing plants with very showy lilylike blossoms,natives of India.
gelid: Cold; very cold; frozen. "Gelid founts." Thompson.
greeze: A step. See Gree, a step. [Obs.]The top of the ladder, or first greeze, is this. Latimer.
gammon: The buttock or tight of a hog, salted and smoked or dried; thelower end of a flitch. Goldsmith.
gaby: A simpleton; a dunce; a lout. [Colloq.]
glass-snake: A long, footless lizard (Ophiosaurus ventralis), of theSouthern United States; -- so called from its fragility, the taileasily breaking into small pieces. It grows to the length of threefeet. The name is applied also to similar species found in the OldWorld.
gypseous: Resembling or containing gypsum; partaking of the qualities ofgypsum.
gutturize: To make in the throat; to gutturalize. [R.]For which the Germans gutturize a sound. Coleridge.
gyrose: Turned round like a crook, or bent to and fro. Loudon.
glutinous: Havig a moist and adhesive or sticky surface, as a leaf orgland.
grasp: To effect a grasp; to make the motion of grasping; to clutch;to struggle; to strive.As one that grasped And tugged for life and was by strength subdued.Shak.To grasp at, to catch at; to try to seize; as, Alexander grasped atuniversal empire,
gaudy: One of the large beads in the rosary at which the paternosteris recited. [Obs.] Gower.
guernsey lily: A South African plant (Nerine Sarniensis) with handsomelilylike flowers, naturalized on the island of Guernsey.
groundling: A fish that keeps at the bottom of the water, as the loach.
glen: A secluded and narrow valley; a dale; a depression betweenhills.And wooes the widow's daughter of the glen. Spenser.
geognost: One versed in geognosy; a geologist. [R.]
gullage: Act of being gulled. [Obs.]Had you no quirk. To avoid gullage, sir, by such a creature B. Jonson
glass-sponge: A siliceous sponge, of the genus Hyalonema, and allied genera;-- so called from their glassy fibers or spicules; -- called alsovitreous sponge. See Glass-rope, and Euplectella.
gossiprede: The relationship between a person and his sponsors. [Obs.]
gigerium: The muscular stomach, or gizzard, of birds.
gravimetric: Of or pertaining to measurement by weight; measured by weight.-- Grav"i*met"ric*al*ly, adv. Gravimetric analysis (Chem.), analysisin which the amounts of the coastituents are determined by weight; --in distinction from volumetric analysis.
gonosome: The reproductive zooids of a hydroid colony, collectively.
gosherd: One who takes care of geese.
guelderrose: A cultivated variety of a species of Viburnum (V. Opulus),bearing large bunches of white flowers; -- called also snowball tree.
gulosity: Excessive appetite; greediness; voracity. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
grugru worm: The larva or grub of a large South American beetle (Calandrapalmarum), which lives in the pith of palm trees and sugar cane. Itis eaten by the natives, and esteemed a delicacy.
globose: Having a rounded form resembling that of a globe; globular, ornearly so; spherical. Milton.
gingham: A kind of cotton or linen cloth, usually in stripes or checks,the yarn of which is dyed before it is woven; -- distinguished fromprinted cotton or prints.
guardianship: The office, duty, or care, of a guardian; protection; care;watch.
greencloth: A board or court of justice formerly held in the counting houseof the British sovereign's household, composed of the lord stewardand his officers, and having cognizance of matters of justice in thehousehold, with power to correct offenders and keep the peace withinthe verge of the palace, which extends two hundred yards beyond thegatees.
gonoph: A pickpocket or thief. [Eng. Slang] Dickens.
gallinae: An order of birds, including the common domestic fowls,pheasants, grouse, quails, and allied forms; -- sometimes calledRasores.
grama grass: The name of several kinds of pasture grasses found in theWestern United States, esp. the Bouteloua oligostachya.
gadding: Going about much, needlessly or without purpose.Envy is a gadding passion, and walketh the streets. Bacon.The good nuns would check her gadding tongue. Tennyson.Gadding car, in quarrying, a car which carries a drilling machine soarranged as to drill a line of holes.
gyneolatry: The adoration or worship of woman.The sentimental gyneolatry of chivalry, which was at best but skin-deep. Lowell.
gyrencephala: The higher orders of Mammalia, in which the cerebrum isconvoluted.-- Gyr"en*ceph"a*lous, a.
grillage: A framework of sleepers and crossbeams forming a foundation inmarshy or treacherous soil.
grass-grown: Overgrown with grass; as, a grass-grown road.
gust: To taste; to have a relish for. [Obs.]
gabeler: A collector of gabels or taxes.
gnosis: The deeper wisdom; knowledge of spiritual truth, such as wasclaimed by the Gnostics.
grapholite: Any species of slate suitable to be written on.
gill-flirt: A thoughtless, giddy girl; a flirt-gill. Sir W. Scott.
gargantuan: Characteristic of Gargantua, a gigantic, wonderful personage;enormous; prodigious; inordinate.
granddaughter: The daughter of one's son or daughter.
gneissoid: Resembling gneiss; having some of the characteristics ofgneiss; -- applied to rocks of an intermediate character betweengranite and gneiss, or mica slate and gneiss.
griever: One who, or that which, grieves.
graving: The act of cleaning a ship's bottom. Graving dock. (Naut.) Seeunder Dock.
gibbose: Humped; protuberant; -- said of a surface which presents one ormore large elevations. Brande & C.
gonidium: A special groove or furrow at one or both angles of the mouthof many Anthozoa.
great-grandmother: The mother of one's grandfather or grandmother.
geosynclinal: the downward bend or subsidence of the earth's crust, whichallows of the gradual accumulation of sediment, and hence forms thefirst step in the making of a mountain range; -- opposed togeanticlinal.
gnatworm: The aquatic larva of a gnat; -- called also, colloquially,wiggler.
gateman: A gate keeper; a gate tender.
gauge: To measure the dimensions of, or to test the accuracy of theform of, as of a part of a gunlock.The vanes nicely gauged on each side. Derham.
gasometer: An apparatus for holding and measuring of gas; in gas works, ahuge iron cylinder closed at one end and having the other endimmersed in water, in which it is made to rise or fall, according tothe volume of gas it contains, or the pressure required.
gablock: A false spur or gaff, fitted on the heel of a gamecock. Wright.
grimly: Grim; hideous; stern. [R.]In glided Margaret's grimly ghost, And stood at William's feet. D.Mallet.
gnathotheca: The horney covering of the lower mandible of a bird.
goggler: A carangoid oceanic fish (Trachurops crumenophthalmus), havingvery large and prominent eyes; -- called also goggle-eye, big-eyedscad, and cicharra.
gamboge: A concrete juice, or gum resin, produced by several species oftrees in Siam, Ceylon, and Malabar. It is brought in masses, orcylindrical rolls, from Cambodia, or Cambogia, -- whence its name.The best kind is of a dense, compact texture, and of a beatifulreddish yellow. Taking internally, it is a strong and harsh catharticad emetic. [Written also camboge.]
german: Nearly related; closely akin.Wert thou a leopard, thou wert german to the lion. Shak.Brother german. See Brother german.-- Cousins german. See the Note under Cousin.
gula: A capping molding. Same as Cymatium.
germanium: A rare element, recently discovered (1885), in a silver ore(argyrodite) at Freiberg. It is a brittle, silver-white metal,chemically intermediate between the metals and nonmetals, resemblestin, and is in general identical with the predicted ekasilicon.Symbol Ge. Atomic weight 72.3.
granatin: Mannite; -- so called because found in the pomegranate.
good-humoredly: With a cheerful spirit; in a cheerful or good-tempered manner.
granilla: Small grains or dust of cochineal or the coccus insect.
groined: Built with groins; as, a groined ceiling; a groined vault.
gaggle: To make a noise like a goose; to cackle. Bacon.
guarantee: The person to whom a guaranty is made; -- the correlative ofguarantor.
germander: A plant of the genus Teucrium (esp. Teucrium Chamædrys or wallgermander), mintlike herbs and low shrubs. American germander,Teucrium Canadense.-- Germander chickweed, Veronica agrestis.-- Water germander, Teucrium Scordium.-- Wood germander, Teucrium Scorodonia.
goman: A husband; a master of a family. [Obs.]
gutter: To become channeled, as a candle when the flame flares in thewind.
glandulation: The situation and structure of the secretory vessels in plants.Martyn.Glandulation respects the secretory vessels, which are eitherglandules, follicles, or utricles. J. Lee.
garner: A granary; a building or place where grain is stored forpreservation.
gripe: A vulture; the griffin. [Obs.]Like a white hind under the gripe's sharp claws. Shak.Gripe's egg, an alchemist's vessel. [Obs.] E. Jonson.
glauberite: A mineral, consisting of the sulphates of soda and lime.
gastropneumatic: Pertaining to the alimentary canal and air passages, and to thecavities connected with them; as, the gastropneumatic mucuosmembranes.
gallied: Worried; flurried; frightened. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
generalness: The condition or quality of being general; frequency;commonness. Sir P. Sidney.
gleet: A transparent mucous discharge from the membrane of theurethra, commonly an effect of gonorrhea. Hoblyn.
grunter: One of several American marine fishes. See Sea robin, andGrunt, n., 2.
gentoo: A native of Hindostan; a Hindoo. [Archaic]
gradatory: Suitable for walking; -- said of the limbs of an animal whenadapted for walking on land.
grape: A well-known edible berry growing in pendent clusters orbunches on the grapevine. The berries are smooth-skinned, have ajuicy pulp, and are cultivated in great quantities for table use andfor making wine and raisins.
gnathidium: The ramus of the lower jaw of a bird as far as it is naked; --commonly used in the plural.
griddlecake: A cake baked or fried on a griddle, esp. a thin batter cake, asof buckwheat or common flour.
grievancer: One who occasions a grievance; one who gives ground forcomplaint. [Obs.]Petition . . . against the bishops as grand grievancers. Fuller.
guttated: Besprinkled with drops, or droplike spots. Bailey.
grilse: A young salmon after its first return from the sea.
goer: One who, or that which, goes; a runner or walker; as:(a) A foot. [Obs.] Chapman.(b) A horse, considered in reference to his gait; as, a good goer; asafe goer.This antechamber has been filled with comers and goers. Macaulay.
gastrology: The science which treats of the structure and functions of thestomach; a treatise of the stomach.
gatherable: Capable of being gathered or collected; deducible frompremises. [R.] Godwin.
gunstome: A cannon ball; -- so called because originally made of stone.[Obs.] Shak.
gadwall: A large duck (Anas strepera), valued as a game bird, found inthe northern parts of Europe and America; -- called also gray duck.[Written also gaddwell.]
gip: To take out the entrails of (herrings).
gathering: Assembling; collecting; used for gathering or concentrating.Gathering board (Bookbinding), a table or board on which signaturesare gathered or assembled, to form a book. Knight.-- Gathering coal, a lighted coal left smothered in embers overnight, about which kindling wood is gathered in the morning.-- Gathering hoop, a hoop used by coopers to draw together the endsof barrel staves, to allow the hoops to be slipped over them.-- Gathering peat. (a) A piece of peat used as a gathering coal, topreserve a fire. (b) In Scotland, a fiery peat which was sent roundby the Borderers as an alarm signal, as the fiery cross was by theHighlanders.
gunnery: That branch of military science which comprehends the theory ofprojectiles, and the manner of constructing and using ordnance.
glandulosity: Quality of being glandulous; a collection of glands. [R.] SirT. Browne.
garreteer: One who lives in a garret; a poor author; a literary hack.Macaulay.
gormandize: To eat greedily; to swallow voraciously; to feed ravenously orlike a glutton. Shak.
gulgul: A cement made in India from sea shells, pulverized and mixedwith oil, and spread over a ship's bottom, to prevent the boring ofworms.
griefful: Full of grief or sorrow. Sackvingle.
glycocholic: Pertaining to, or composed of, glycocoll and cholic acid.Glycocholic acid (Physiol. Chem.), a conjugate acid, composed ofglycocoll and cholic acid, present in bile in the form of a sodiumsalt. The acid commonly forms a resinous mass, but can becrystallized in long, white needles.
gite: A gown. [Obs.]She came often in a gite of red. Chaucer.
guardless: Without a guard or defense; unguarded. Chapman.
greeting: Expression of kindness or joy; salutation at meeting; acompliment from one absent.Write to him . . . gentle adieus and greetings. Shak.
germinative: Pertaining to germination; having power to bud or develop.Germinative spot, Germinative vesicle. (Biol.) Same as Germinal spot,Germinal vesicle, under Germinal.
guaiacol: A colorless liquid, C7H8O2, with a peculiar odor. It is themethyl ether of pyrocatechin, and is obtained by distilling guaiacumfrom wood-tar creosote, and in other ways. It has been used intreating pulmonary tuberculosis.
grecque: An ornament supposed to be of Greek origin, esp. a fret ormeander,
gantline: A line rigged to a mast; -- used in hoisting rigging; agirtline.
gabelle: A tax, especially on salt. [France] Brande & C.
guidable: Capable of being guided; willing to be guided or counseled.Sprat.
golden-eye: A duck (Glaucionetta clangula), found in Northern Europe, Asia,and America. The American variety (var. Americana) is larger. Calledwhistler, garrot, gowdy, pied widgeon, whiteside, curre, and doucker.Barrow's golden-eye of America (G. Islandica) is less common.
goneness: A state of exhaustion; faintness, especially as resulting fromhunger. [Colloq. U. S.]
geometrize: To investigate or apprehend geometrical quantities or laws; tomake geometrical constructions; to proceed in accordance with theprinciples of geometry.Nature geometrizeth, and observeth order in all things. Sir T.Browne.
gorgon: One of three fabled sisters, Stheno, Euryale, and Medusa, withsnaky hair and of terrific aspect, the sight of whom turned thebeholder to stone. The name is particularly given to Medusa.
gorget: A crescent-shaped, colored patch on the neck of a bird ormammal. Gorget hummer (Zoöl.), a humming bird of the genus Trochilus.See Rubythroat.
gentlemanhood: The qualities or condition of a gentleman. [R.] Thackeray.
grillroom: A room specially fitted for broiling food, esp. one in arestaurant, hotel, or clubhouse, arranged for prompt service.
glyoxalic: Pertaining to, or designating, an aldehyde acid, intermediatebetween glycol and oxalic acid. [Written also glyoxylic.]
gavelet: An ancient special kind of cessavit used in Kent and London forthe recovery of rent. [Obs.]
guerrilla: Pertaining to, or engaged in, warfare carried on irregularlyand by independent bands; as, a guerrilla party; guerrilla warfare.
guilor: A deceiver; one who deludes, or uses guile. [Obs.] Spenser.
glaucophane: A mineral of a dark bluish color, related to amphibole. It ischaracteristic of certain crystalline rocks.
greco-roman: Having characteristics that are partly Greek and partly Roman;as, Greco-Roman architecture.
gluttonous: Given to gluttony; eating to excess; indulging the appetite;voracious; as, a gluttonous age.-- Glut"ton*ous*ly, adv.-- Glut"ton*ous*ness, n.
gauze: A very thin, slight, transparent stuff, generally of silk;also, any fabric resembling silk gauze; as, wire gauze; cotton gauze.Gauze dresser, one employed in stiffening gauze.
glossic: A system of phonetic spelling based upon the present values ofEnglish letters, but invariably using one symbol to represent onesound only.Ingglish Glosik konvaiA. J. Ellis.
gorgoneion: A mask carved in imitation of a Gorgon's head. Elmes.
go-out: A sluice in embankments against the sea, for letting out theland waters, when the tide is out. [Written also gowt.]
gastropod: One of the Gastropoda. [Written also gasteropod.]
glomerulus: The bunch of looped capillary blood vessels in a Malpighiancapsule of the kidney.
gumminess: The state or quality of being gummy; viscousness.
grammates: Rudiments; first principles, as of grammar. [Obs.] Ford.
galactophagist: One who eats, or subsists on, milk.
growl: To utter a deep guttural sound, sa an angry dog; to give forthan angry, grumbling sound. Gay.
gammadion: A cross formed of four capital gammas, formerly used as amysterious ornament on ecclesiastical vestments, etc. See Fylfot.
gadfly: Any dipterous insect of the genus Oestrus, and allied genera ofbotflies.
gaucho: On of the native inhabitants of the pampas, of Spanish-Americandescent. They live mostly by rearing cattle.
grate: Serving to gratify; agreeable. [Obs.] Sir T. Herbert.
gymnoblastea: The Athecata; -- so called because the medusoid buds are notinclosed in a capsule.
glutaconic: Pertaining to, or derived from, an acid intermediate betweenglutaric and aconitic acids.
gliding machine: A construction consisting essentially of one or more aëroplanesfor gliding in an inclined path from a height to the ground.
gunter rig: A topmast arranged with metal bands so that it will readilyslide up and down the lower mast.
gremial: Of or pertaining to the lap or bosom. [R.]
gainsayer: One who gainsays, contradicts, or denies. "To convince thegainsayers." Tit. i. 9.
gather: To bring together, or nearer together, in masonry, as where thewidth of a fireplace is rapidly diminished to the width of the flue,or the like.
greisen: A crystalline rock consisting of quarts and mica, common in thetin regions of Cornwall and Saxony.
gunshot: Made by the shot of a gun: as. a gunshot wound.
gormand: A greedy or ravenous eater; a luxurious feeder; a gourmand.
gnosticism: The system of philosophy taught by the Gnostics.
glimpse: to appear by glimpses; to catch glimpses. Drayton.
grisly: Frightful; horrible; dreadful; harsh; as, grisly locks; agrisly specter. "Grisly to behold." Chaucer.A man of grisly and stern gravity. Robynson (More's Utopia).Grisly bear. (Zoöl.) See under Grizzly.
gormandizer: A greedy, voracious eater; a gormand; a glutton.
gavial: A large Asiatic crocodilian (Gavialis Gangeticus); -- calledalso nako, and Gangetic crocodile.
goose egg: In games, a zero; a score or record of naught; -- so named inallusion to the egglike outline of the zero sign 0. Called also duckegg. [Slang]
ghibelline: One of a faction in Italy, in the 12th and 13th centuries,which favored the German emperors, and opposed the Guelfs, oradherents of the poses. Brande & C.
gynander: A plant having the stamens inserted in the pistil.
gyromancy: A kind of divination performed by drawing a ring or circle, andwalking in or around it. Brande & C.
gossipy: Full of, or given to, gossip.
griffin: An Anglo-Indian name for a person just arrived from Europe. H.Kingsley.
gems-horn: An organ stop with conical tin pipes.
gascon: Of or pertaining to Gascony, in France, or to the Gascons;also, braggart; swaggering.-- n.
geoponics: The art or science of cultivating the earth; agriculture.Evelin.
gurjun: A thin balsam or wood oil derived from the Diptcrocarpus lævis,an East Indian tree. It is used in medicine, and as a substitute forlinseed oil in the coarser kinds of paint.
gap-toothed: Having interstices between the teeth. Dryden.
goodish: Rather good than the contrary; not actually bad; tolerable.Goodish pictures in rich frames. Walpole.
gladiator: Of or pertaining to gladiators, or to contests or combatants ingeneral.
gastriloquy: A voice or utterance which appears to proceed from the stomach;ventriloquy.
gold-beating: The art or process of reducing gold to extremely thin leaves,by beating with a hammer. Ure.
getter: One who gets, gains, obtains, acquires, begets, or procreates.
gib-cat: A male cat, esp. an old one. See lst Gib. n. [Obs.] Shak.
graveness: The quality of being grave.His sables and his weeds, Importing health and graveness. Shak.
gaseity: State of being gaseous. [R] Eng. Cyc.
gatten tree: A name given to the small trees called guelder-rose (ViburnumOpulus), cornel (Cornus sanguinea), and spindle tree (EuonymusEuropæus).
glyptodont: One of a family (glyptodontidæ) of extinct South Americanedentates, of which Glyptodon is the type. About twenty species areknown.
greengill: An oyster which has the gills tinged with a green pigment, saidto be due to an abnormal condition of the blood.
ginseng: A plant of the genus Aralia, the root of which is highly valuedas a medicine among the Chinese. The Chinese plant (Aralia Schinseng)has become so rare that the American (A. quinquefolia) has largelytaken its place, and its root is now an article of export fromAmerica to China. The root, when dry, is of a yellowish white color,with a sweetness in the taste somewhat resembling that of licorice,combined with a slight aromatic bitterness.
glossal: Of or pertaining to the tongue; lingual.
galvanoplastic: Of or pertaining to the art or process of electrotyping;employing, or produced by, the process of electolytic deposition; as,a galvano-plastic copy of a medal or the like.
gloat: To look steadfastly; to gazIn vengeance gloating on another's pain. Byron.
grisliness: The quality or state of being grisly; horrid. Sir P. Sidney.
glyoxal: A white, amorphous, deliquescent powder, (CO.H)2, obtained bythe partial oxidation of glycol. It is a double aldehyde, betweenglycol and oxalic acid.
glyptodon: An extinct South American quaternary mammal, allied to thearmadillos. It was as large as an ox, was covered with tessellatedscales, and had fluted teeth. Owen.
glires: An order of mammals; the Rodentia.-- Gli"rine, a.
genevan: Of or pertaining to Geneva, in Switzerland; Genevese.
gluten: The viscid, tenacious substance which gives adhesiveness todough.
ginshop: A shop or barroom where gin is sold as a beverage. [Colloq.]
glauconite: The green mineral characteristic of the greensand of the chalkand other formations. It is a hydrous silicate of iron and potash.See Greensand.
gasteromycetes: An order of fungi, in which the spores are borne inside a saccalled the peridium, as in the puffballs.
grosbeak: One of various species of finches having a large, stout beak.The common European grosbeak or hawfinch is Coccothraustes vulgaris.
gymnoglossa: A division of gastropods in which the odontophore is withoutteeth.
grieve: To feel grief; to be in pain of mind on account of an evil; tosorrow; to mourn; -- often followed by at, for, or over.Do not you grieve at this. Shak.
goroon shell: A large, handsome, marine, univalve shell (Triton femorale).
gauging rod: See Gauge rod, under Gauge, n.
gymnastics: Athletic or disciplinary exercises; the art of performinggymnastic exercises; also, disciplinary exercises for the intellector character.
glasswork: Manufacture of glass; articles or ornamentation made of glass.
gerah: A small coin and weight; 1-20th of a shekel.
guerdon: A reward; requital; recompense; -- used in both a good and abad sense. Macaulay.So young as to regard men's frown or smile As loss or guerdon of aglorious lot. Byron.He shall, by thy revenging hand, at once receive the just guerdon ofall his former villainies. Knolles.
gallstone: A concretion, or calculus, formed in the gall bladder orbiliary passages. See Calculus, n., 1.
ganesa: The Hindoo god of wisdom or prudence.
gastrotricha: A group of small wormlike animals, having cilia on the ventralside. The group is regarded as an ancestral or synthetic one, relatedto rotifers and annelids.
grocer: A trader who deals in tea, sugar, spices, coffee, fruits, andvarious other commodities. Grocer's itch (Med.), a disease of theakin, caused by handling sugar and treacle.
ganocephala: A group of fossil amphibians allied to the labyrinthodonts,having the head defended by bony, sculptured plates, as in someganoid fishes.
geologize: To study geology or make geological investigations in thefield; to discourse as a geologist.During midsummer geologized a little in Shropshire. Darwin.
glyceride: A compound ether (formed from glycerin). Some glycerides existready formed as natural fats, others are produced artificially.
godhood: Divine nature or essence; deity; godhead.
gentianic: Pertaining to or derived from the gentian; as, gentianic acid.
genitocrural: Pertaining to the genital organs and the thigh; -- appliedespecially to one of the lumbar nerves.
galloping: Going at a gallop; progressing rapidly; as, a galloping horse.
gor-belly: A prominent belly; a big-bellied person. [Obs.]
genitals: The organs of generation; the sexual organs; the private parts.
grated: Furnished with a grate or grating; as, grated windows.
goemin: A complex mixture of several substances extracted from Irishmoss.
graduality: The state of being gradual; gradualness. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
galoot: A noisy, swaggering, or worthless fellow; a rowdy. [Slang, U.S.]
garganey: A small European duck (Anas querquedula); -- called alsocricket teal, and summer teal.
gap: An opening in anything made by breaking or parting; as, a gapin a fence; an opening for a passage or entrance; an opening whichimplies a breach or defect; a vacant space or time; a hiatus; amountain pass.Miseries ensued by the opening of that gap. Knolles.It would make a great gap in your own honor. Shak.Gap lathe (Mach.), a turning lathe with a deep notch in the bed toadmit of turning a short object of large diameter.-- To stand in the gap, to expose one's self for the protection ofsomething; to make defense against any assailing danger; to take theplace of a fallen defender or supporter.-- To stop a gap, to secure a weak point; to repair a defect.
gastrotrocha: A form of annelid larva having cilia on the ventral side.
gassy: Full of gas; like gas. Hence: [Colloq.] Inflated; full ofboastful or insincere talk.
graille: A halfround single-cut file or fioat, having one curved faceand one straight face, -- used by comb makers. Knight.
ginhouse: A building where cotton is ginned.
godild: A corruption of God yield, i. e., God reward or bless. Shak.
garlic: A plant of the genus Allium (A. sativum is the cultivatedvariety), having a bulbous root, a very strong smell, and an acrid,pungent taste. Each root is composed of several lesser bulbs, calledcloves of garlic, inclosed in a common membranous coat, and easilyseparable.
gem: A bud.From the joints of thy prolific stem A swelling knot is raised calleda gem. Denham.
gamic: Pertaining to, or resulting from, sexual connection; formed bythe union of the male and female elements.
gabionade: A traverse made with gabions between guns or on their flanks,protecting them from enfilading fire.
geodephagous: Living in the earth; -- applied to the ground beetles.
groveling: Lying prone; low; debased. [Written also grovelling.] "Agroveling creature." Cowper.
groggy: Moving in a hobbling manner, owing to ten der feet; -- said ofa horse. Youatt.
garvie: The spart; -- called also garvie herring, and garvock. [Prov.Eng. & Scot.]
gradus: A dictionary of prosody, designed as an aid in writing Greek orLatin poetry.He set to work . . . without gradus or other help. T. Hughes.
gauffering: A mode of plaiting or fluting. Gauffering iron, a kind offluting iron for fabrics.-- Gauffering press (Flower Manuf.), a press for crimping the leavesand petals into shape.
gleba: The chambered sporogenous tissue forming the central mass ofthe sporophore in puff balls, stinkhorns, etc.
ginging: The lining of a mine shaft with stones or bricks to preventcaving.
granular: Consisting of, or resembling, grains; as, a granular substance.Granular limestone, crystalline limestone, or marble, having agranular structure.
gunnie: Space left by the removal of ore.
gadsman: One who uses a gad or goad in driving.
germ cell: A cell, of either sex, directly concerned in the production ofa new organism.
