generalissimo: The chief commander of an army; especially, the commander inchief of an army consisting of two or more grand divisions underseparate commanders; -- a title used in most foreign countries.
gluttony: Excess in eating; extravagant indulgence of the appetite forfood; voracity.Their sumptuous gluttonies, and gorgeous feasts. Milton.
glunch: Frowning; sulky; sullen. Sir W. Scott.-- n.
griffe: The offspring of a mulatto woman and a negro; also, a mulatto.[Local, U. S.]
gulf: A portion of an ocean or sea extending into the land; apartially land-locked sea; as, the Gulf of Mexico.
gralline: Of or pertaining to the Grallæ.
grandeur: The state or quality of being grand; vastness; greatness;splendor; magnificence; stateliness; sublimity; dignity; elevation ofthought or expression; nobility of action.Nor doth this grandeur and majestic show Of luxury . . . allure mineeye. Milton.
guly: Of or pertaining to gules; red. "Those fatal guly dragons."Milton.
gonophore: A sexual zooid produced as a medusoid bud upon a hydroid,sometimes becoming a free hydromedusa, sometimes remaining attached.See Hydroidea, and Illusts. of Athecata, Campanularian, and Gonosome.
glyphograph: A plate made by glyphography, or an impression taken from sucha plate.
grisons: The largest and most eastern of the Swiss cantons.
grossly: In a gross manner; greatly; coarsely; without delicacy;shamefully; disgracefully.
gowdnook: The saury pike; -- called also gofnick.
gastroscope: An instrument for viewing or examining the interior of thestomach.
geostatic: Relating to the pressure exerted by earth or similar substance.Geostatic arch, an arch having a form adapted to sustain pressuresimilar to that exerted by earth. Rankine.
grasshopper: Any jumping, orthopterous insect, of the families Acrididæ andLocustidæ. The species and genera are very numerous. The formerfamily includes the Western grasshopper or locust (Caloptenusspretus), noted for the great extent of its ravages in the regionbeyond the Mississippi. In the Eastern United States the red-legged(Caloptenus femurrubrum and C. atlanis) are closely related species,but their ravages are less important. They are closely related to themigratory locusts of the Old World. See Locust.
gastroduodenitis: Inflammation of the stomach and duodenum. It is one of the mostfrequent causes of jaundice.
generalia: Generalities; general terms. J. S. Mill.
glad: To make glad; to cheer; to gladden; to exhilarate. Chaucer.That which gladded all the warrior train. Dryden.Each drinks the juice that glads the heart of man. Pope.
gossypium: A genus of plants which yield the cotton of the arts. Thespecies are much confused. G. herbaceum is the name given to thecommon cotton plant, while the long-stapled sea-island cotton isproduced by G. Barbadense, a shrubby variety. There are several otherkinds besides these.
gravimeter: (Physics) An instrument for ascertaining the specific gravityof bodies.
gagger: A piece of iron imbedded in the sand of a mold to keep the sandin place.
gauger: One who gauges; an officer whose business it is to ascertainthe contents of casks.
globy: Resembling, or pertaining to, a globe; round; orbicular. "Thegloby sea." Milton.
gripper: In printing presses, the fingers or nippers.
gelable: Capable of being congealed; capable of being converted intojelly.
gillian: A girl; esp., a wanton; a gill. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
gratin: The brown crust formed upon a gratinated dish; also, dishitself, as crusts bread, game, or poultry.
gramme machine: A kind of dynamo-electric machine; -- so named from its Frenchinventor, M. Gramme. Knight.
glutaeus: The great muscle of the buttock in man and most mammals, andthe corresponding muscle in many lower animals.
gratulation: The act of gratulating or felicitating; congratulation.I shall turn my wishes into gratulations. South.
grotesquery: Grotesque action, speech, or manners; grotesque doings. "Thesustained grotesquery of Feather-top."  K. L. Bates.
garniture: That which garnishes; ornamental appendage; embellishment;furniture; dress.The pomp of groves and garniture of fields. Beattie.
gyron: A subordinary of triangular form having one of its angles atthe fess point and the opposite aide at the edge of the escutcheon.When there is only one gyron on the shield it is bounded by two lineadrawn from the fess point, one horizontally to the dexter side, andone to the dexter chief corner.
gadolinium: A supposed rare metallic element, with a characteristicspectrum, found associated with yttrium and other rare metals. Itsindividuality and properties have not yet been determined.
gangway: The opening through the bulwarks of a vessel by which personsenter or leave it.
glisten: To sparkle or shine; especially, to shine with a mild, subdued,and fitful luster; to emit a soft, scintillating light; to gleam; as,the glistening stars.
gymnasiarch: An Athenian officer who superintended the gymnasia, andprovided the oil and other necessaries at his own expense.
gully: A large knife. [Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
gamekeeper: One who has the care of game, especially in a park or preserve.Blackstone.
gamy: Having the flavor of game, esp. of game kept uncooked till nearthe condition of tainting; high-flavored.
guileless: Free from guile; artless.-- Guile"less*ly, adv. Guile"less*ness, n.
grandee: A man of elevated rank or station; a nobleman. In Spain, anobleman of the first rank, who may be covered in the king'spresence.
gens: A minor subdivision of a tribe, among American aborigines. Itincludes those who have a common descent, and bear the same totem.
gallows: The rest for the tympan when raised.
gynantherous: Pertaining to an abnormal condition of the flower, in which thestamens are converted into pistils. A. Brown.
gallican: Of or pertaining to Gaul or France; Gallic; French; as, theGallican church or clergy.
grumble: To express or utter with grumbling.
gallow: To fright or terrify. See Gally, v. t. [Obs.] Shak.
globefish: A plectognath fish of the genera Diodon, Tetrodon, and alliedgenera. The globefishes can suck in water or air and distend the bodyto a more or less globular form. Called also porcupine fish, and seahedgehog. See Diodon.
graphoscope: An optical instrument for magnifying engravings, photographs,etc., usually having one large lens and two smaller ones.
grindstone: A flat, circular stone, revolving on an axle, for grinding orsharpening tools, or shaping or smoothing objects. To hold, pat, orbring one's nose to the grindstone, to oppress one; to keep one in acondition of servitude.They might be ashamed, for lack of courage, to suffer theLacedæmonians to hold their noses to the grindstone. Sir T. North.
gladen: Sword grass; any plant with sword-shaped leaves, esp. theEuropean Iris foetidissima. [Written also gladwyn, gladdon, andglader.]
generalizable: Capable of being generalized, or reduced to a general form ofstatement, or brought under a general rule.Extreme cases are . . . not generalizable. Coleridge
gesture: To accompany or illustrate with gesture or action; togesticulate.It is not orderly read, nor gestured as beseemeth. Hooker.
gastrocnemius: The muscle which makes the greater part of the calf of the leg.
glaucous: Covered with a fine bloom or fine white powder easily rubbedoff, as that on a blue plum, or on a cabbage leaf. Gray.
glomerate: Gathered together in a roundish mass or dense cluster;conglomerate.
graham bread: Bread made of unbolted wheat flour. [U. S.] Bartlett.
graft: To implant a portion of (living flesh or akin) in a lesion soas to form an organic union.
gang-flower: The common English milkwort (Polygala vulgaris), so called fromblossoming in gang week. Dr. Prior.
galliform: Like the Gallinae (or Galliformes) in structure.
gribble: A small marine isopod crustacean (Limnoria lignorum or L.terebrans), which burrows into and rapidly destroys submerged timber,such as the piles of wharves, both in Europe and America.
goldcrest: The European golden-crested kinglet (Regulus cristatus, or R.regulus); -- called also golden-crested wren, and golden wren. Thename is also sometimes applied to the American golden-crestedkinglet. See Kinglet.
giddy-head: A person without thought fulness, prudence, or judgment.[Colloq.] Burton.
grundyism: Narrow and unintelligent conventionalism. -- Grun"dy*ist, n.
gunpowder: A black, granular, explosive substance, consisting of anintimate mechanical mixture of niter, charcoal, and sulphur. It isused in gunnery and blasting.
geophagist: One who eats earth, as dirt, clay, chalk, etc.
gyroidal: Having the planes arranged spirally, so that they incline allto the right (or left) of a vertical line; -- said of certainhemihedral forms.
gravidity: The state of being gravidated; pregnancy. [R.]
graffito: Production of decorative designs by scratching them through asurface of layer plaster, glazing, etc., revealing a different-colored ground; also, pottery or ware so decorated; -- chiefly usedattributively.
gamomorphism: That stage of growth or development in an organism, in whichthe reproductive elements are generated and matured in preparationfor propagating the species.
gyrostatics: The doctrine or theory of the gyrostat, or of the phenomena ofrotating bodies.
glutinate: To unite with glue; to cement; to stick together. Bailey.
gland: The movable part of a stuffing box by which the packing iscompressed; -- sometimes called a follower. See Illust. of Stuffingbox, under Stuffing.
guiacol: A colorless liquid, C6H4,OCH3.OH, resembling the phenols, foundas a constituent of woodtar creosote, aud produced by the drydistillation of guaiac resin.
gyve: A shackle; especially, one to confine the legs; a fetter.[Written also give.]Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves. Shak.With gyves upon his wrist. Hood.
gutwort: A plant, Globularia Alypum, a violent purgative, found inAfrica.
gon: imp. & p. p. of Go. [Obs.] Chaucer.
gouge: Soft material lying between the wall of a vein aud the solidvein. Raymond.
geometrid: Pertaining or belonging to the Geometridæ.
ghee: Butter clarified by boiling, and thus converted into a kind ofoil. [India] Malcom.
gallinule: One of several wading birds, having long, webless toes, and afrontal shield, belonging to the family Rallidae. They are remarkablefor running rapidly over marshes and on floating plants. The purplegallinule of America is Ionornis Martinica, that of the Old World isPorphyrio porphyrio. The common European gallinule (Gallinulachloropus) is also called moor hen, water hen, water rail, moor coot,night bird, and erroneously dabchick. Closely related to it is theFlorida gallinule (Gallinula galeata).
gwiniad: A fish (Coregonus ferus) of North Wales and Northern Europe,allied to the lake whitefish; -- called also powan, and schelly.[Written also gwyniad, guiniad, gurniad.]
gongorism: An affected elegance or euphuism of style, for which theSpanish poet Gongora y Argote (1561-1627), among others of his time,was noted.
gentisin: A tasteless, yellow, crystalline substance, obtained from thegentian; -- called also gentianin.
galvanometric: Of, pertaining to, or measured by, a galvanometer.
gridiron: An openwork frame on which vessels are placed for examination,cleaning, and repairs. 3. (Sport)
grenadier: Originaly, a soldier who carried and threw grenades; afterward,one of a company attached to each regiment or battalion, taking poston the right of the line, and wearing a peculiar uniform. In moderntimes, a member of a special regiment or corps; as, a grenadier ofthe guard of Napoleon I. one of the regiment of Grenadier Guards ofthe British army, etc.
glass-gazing: Given to viewing one's self in a glass or mirror; finical.[Poetic] Shak.
gorgonzola: A kind of Italian pressed milk cheese; -- so called from avillage near Milan.
giganticide: The act of killing, or one who kills, a giant. Hallam.
gargoyle: A spout projecting from the roof gutter of a building, oftencarved grotesquely. [Written also gargle, gargyle, and gurgoyle.]
goliardery: The satirical or ribald poetry of the Goliards. Milman.
gallimatia: Senseless talk. [Obs. or R.] See Galimatias.
groper: One who gropes; one who feels his way in the dark, or searchesby feeling.
gelastic: Pertaining to laughter; used in laughing. "Gelastic muscles."Sir T. Browne.
glosser: A polisher; one who gives a luster.
gyre: A circular motion, or a circle described by a moving body; aturn or revolution; a circuit.Quick and more quick he spins in giddy gyres. Dryden.Still expanding and ascending gyres. Mrs. Browning.
geezer: A queer old fellow; an old chap; an old woman. [Contemptuous,Slang or Dial.]
gobline: One of the ropes or chains serving as stays for the dolphinstriker or the bowsprit; -- called also gobrope and gaubline.
gilder: One who gilds; one whose occupation is to overlay with gold.
garrote: A Spanish mode of execution by strangulation, with an ironcollar affixed to a post and tightened by a screw until life becomeextinct; also, the instrument by means of which the punishment isinflicted.
genethliacs: The science of calculating nativities, or predicting the futureevents of life from the stars which preside at birth. Jhonson.
gratitude: The state of being grateful; warm and friendly feeling toward abenefactor; kindness awakened by a favor received; thankfulness.The debt immense of endless gratitude. Milton.
grapevine: A vine or climbing shrub, of the genus Vitis, having smallgreen flowers and lobed leaves, and bearing the fruit called grapes.
grimy: Full of grime; begrimed; dirty; foul.
gudgeon: A small European freshwater fish (Gobio fluviatilis), allied tothe carp. It is easily caught and often used for food and for bait.In America the killifishes or minnows are often called gudgeons.
gibberish: Rapid and inarticulate talk; unintelligible language; unmeaningwords; jargon.He, like a gypsy, oftentimes would go; All kinds of gibberish he hadlearnt to known. Drayton.Such gibberish as children may be heard amusing themselves with.Hawthorne.
gibe: To cast reproaches and sneering expressions; to rail; to uttertaunting, sarcastic words; to flout; to fleer; to scoff.Fleer and gibe, and laugh and flout. Swift.
grader: 1. One who grades, or that by means of which grading is done orfacilitate.
guiltiness: The quality or state of being guilty.
grapnel: A small anchor, with four or five flukes or claws, used to holdboats or small vessels; hence, any instrument designed to grapple orhold; a grappling iron; a grab; -- written also grapline, andcrapnel.
glimmer: To give feeble or scattered rays of light; to shine faintly; toshow a faint, unsteady light; as, the glimmering dawn; a glimmeringlamp.The west yet glimmers with some streaks of day. Shak.
gab: The hook on the end of an eccentric rod opposite the strap.See. Illust. of Eccentric.
greensand: A variety of sandstone, usually imperfectly consolidated,consisting largely of glauconite, a silicate of iron and potash of agreen color, mixed with sand and a trace of phosphate of lime.
gemmeous: Pertaining to gems; of the nature of gems; resembling gems.Pennant.
glycocholate: A salt of glycocholic acid; as, sodium glycocholate.
girondist: A member of the moderate republican party formed in the Frenchlegislative assembly in 1791. The Girondists were so called becausetheir leaders were deputies from the department of La Gironde.
goatfish: A fish of the genus Upeneus, inhabiting the Gulf of Mexico. Itis allied to the surmullet.
gratinate: To cook, as macaroni, in a savory juice or sauce until juice isabsorbed and a crisp surface forms.
grail: A book of offices in the Roman Catholic Church; a gradual.[Obs.] T. Warton.Such as antiphonals, missals, grails, processionals, etc. Strype.
greenockite: Native cadmium sulphide, a mineral occurring in yellowhexagonal crystals, also as an earthy incrustation.
gamete: A sexual cell or germ cell; a conjugating cell which uniteswith another of like or unlike character to form a new individual. InBot., gamete designates esp. the similar sex cells of the lowerthallophytes which unite by conjugation, forming a zygospore. Thegametes of higher plants are of two sorts, sperm (male) and egg(female); their union is called fertilization, and the resultingzygote an oöspore. In Zoöl., gamete is most commonly used of thesexual cells of certain Protozoa, though also extended to the germcells of higher forms.
gravedigger: See Burying beetle, under Bury, v. t.
great-granddaughter: A daughter of one's grandson or granddaughter.
greasiness: The quality or state of being greasy, oiliness; unctuousness;grossness.
gusset: An abatement or mark of dishonor in a coat of arms, resemblinga gusset.
grouping: The disposal or relative arrangement of figures or objects, asin, drawing, painting, and sculpture, or in ornamental design.
glycosine: An organic base, C6H6N4, produced artificially as a white,crystalline powder, by the action of ammonia on glyoxal.
gnathite: Any one of the mouth appendages of the Arthropoda. They areknown as mandibles, maxillæ, and maxillipeds.
grinte: imp. of Grin, v. i., 1.[He] grinte with his teeth, so was he wroth. Chaucer.
growthead: A lazy person; a blockhead. [Obs.] Tusser.
glacier: An immense field or stream of ice, formed in the region ofperpetual snow, and moving slowly down a mountain slope or valley, asin the Alps, or over an extended area, as in Greenland.
good now: An exclamation of wonder, surprise, or entreaty. [Obs.] Shak.
gaselier: A chandelier arranged to burn gas.
granivorous: Eating grain; feeding or subsisting on seeds; as, granivorousbirds. Gay.
groundly: Solidly; deeply; thoroughly. [Obs.]Those whom princes do once groundly hate, Let them provide to die assure us fate. Marston.
ganza: A kind of wild goose, by a flock of which a virtuoso was fabledto be carried to the lunar world. [Also gansa.] Johnson.
glooming: Twilight (of morning or evening); the gloaming.When the faint glooming in the sky First lightened into day. Trench.The balmy glooming, crescent-lit. Tennyson.
gat-toothed: Goat-toothed; having a lickerish tooth; lustful; wanton. [Obs.]
gustatory: Pertaining to, or subservient to, the sense of taste; as, thegustatory nerve which supplies the front of the tongue.
gossat: A small British marine fish (Motella tricirrata); -- calledalso whistler and three-bearded rockling. [Prov. Eng.]
go-by: A passing without notice; intentional neglect; thrusting away;a shifting off; adieu; as, to give a proposal the go-by.Some songs to which we have given the go-by. Prof. Wilson.
granary: A storehouse or repository for grain, esp. after it is thrashedor husked; a cornbouse; also (Fig.), a region fertile in grain.The exhaustless granary of a world. Thomson.
gangrene: A term formerly restricted to mortification of the soft tissueswhich has not advanced so far as to produce complete loss ofvitality; but now applied to mortification of the soft parts in anystage.
gastight: So tightly fitted as to preclude the escape of gas; imperviousto gas.
gainsborough hat: A woman's broad-brimmed hat of a form thought to resemble thoseshown in portraits by Thomas Gainsborough, the English artist (1727-88).
genealogist: One who traces genealogies or the descent of persons orfamilies.
guib: A West African antelope (Tragelaphus scriptus), curiouslymarked with white stripes and spots on a reddish fawn ground, andhence called harnessed antelope; -- called also guiba.
gleaning: The act of gathering after reapers; that which is collected bygleaning.Glenings of natural knowledge. Cook.
gypsoplast: A cast taken in plaster of Paris, or in white lime.
godsend: Something sent by God; an unexpected acquisiton or piece ofgood fortune.
gold: A metallic element, constituting the most precious metal usedas a common commercial medium of exchange. It has a characteristicyellow color, is one of the heaviest substances known (specificgravity 19.32), is soft, and very malleable and ductile. It is quiteunalterable by heat, moisture, and most corrosive agents, andtherefore well suited for its use in coin and jewelry. Symbol Au(Aurum). Atomic weight 196.7.
green-broom: A plant of the genus Genista (G. tinctoria); dyer's weed; --called also greenweed.
ginglymodi: An order of ganoid fishes, including the modern gar pikes andmany allied fossil forms. They have rhombic, ganoid scales, aheterocercal tail, paired fins without an axis, fulcra on the fins,and a bony skeleton, with the vertebræ convex in front and concavebehind, forming a ball and socket joint. See Ganoidel.
grubber: One who, or that which, grubs; especially, a machine or tool ofthe nature of a grub ax, .grub hook, etc.
gemmation: The formation of a new individual, either animal or vegetable,by a process of budding; an asexual method of reproduction;gemmulation; gemmiparity. See Budding.
greenshank: A European sandpiper or snipe (Totanus canescens); -- calledalso greater plover.
glassen: Glassy; glazed. [Obs.]And pursues the dice with glassen eyes. B. Jonson.
grip car: A car with a grip to clutch a traction cable.
granite: A crystalline, granular rock, consisting of quartz, feldspar,and mica, and usually of a whitish, grayish, or flesh-red color. Itdiffers from gneiss in not having the mica in planes, and therefor inbeing destitute of a schistose structure.
genouillere: A metal plate covering the knee.
gallature: The tread, treadle, or chalasa of an egg.
girlish: Like, or characteristic of, a girl; of or pertaining togirlhood; innocent; artless; immature; weak; as, girlish ways;girlish grief.-- Girl"ish*ly, adv.-- Girl"ish*ness, n.
globulin: An albuminous body, insoluble in water, but soluble in dilutesolutions of salt. It is present in the red blood corpuscles unitedwith hæmatin to form hæmoglobin. It is also found in the crystallinelens of the eye, and in blood serum, and is sometimes calledcrystallin. In the plural the word is applied to a group of proteidsubstances such as vitellin, myosin, fibrinogen, etc., all insolublein water, but soluble in dilute salt solutions.
glede: The common European kite (Milvus ictinus). This name is alsosometimes applied to the buzzard. [Written also glead, gled, gleed,glade, and glide.]
grazer: One that grazes; a creature which feeds on growing grass orherbage.The cackling goose, Close grazer, finds wherewith to ease her want.J. Philips.
gyrus: A convoluted ridge between grooves; a convolution; as, the gyriof the brain; the gyri of brain coral. See Brain.
gamesome: Gay; sportive; playful; frolicsome; merry. Shak.Gladness of the gamesome crowd. Byron.-- Game"some*ly, adv.-- Game"some*ness, n.
gratiolin: One of the essential principles of the hedge hyssop (Gratiolaofficinalis).
glycogen: A white, amorphous, tasteless substance resembling starch,soluble in water to an opalescent fluid. It is found abundantly inthe liver of most animals, and in small quantity in other organs andtissues, particularly in the embryo. It is quickly changed into sugarwhen boiled with dilute sulphuric or hydrochloric acid, and also bythe action of amylolytic ferments.
gullet: The tube by which food and drink are carried from the pharynxto the stomach; the esophagus.
guilder: A Dutch silver coin worth about forty cents; -- called alsoflorin and gulden.
gemarist: One versed in the Gemara, or adhering to its teachings.
governor general: A governor who has lieutenant or deputy governors under him;as, the governor general of Canada, of India.
grugru palm: A West Indian name for several kinds of palm. See Macaw tree,under Macaw. [Written also grigri palm.]
glutamic: Of or pertaining to gluten. Glutamic acid, a nitrogenousorganic acid obtained from certain albuminoids, as gluten; -- calledalso amido-glutaric acid.C5H9NO4.
grasper: One who grasps or seizes; one who catches or holds.
grandnephew: The grandson of one's brother or sister.
gunstock: The stock or wood to which the barrel of a hand gun isfastened.
guan: Any one of many species of large gallinaceous birds of Certaland South America, belonging to Penelope, Pipile, Ortalis, and alliedgenera. Several of the species are often domesticated.
gestant: Bearing within; laden; burdened; pregnant. [R.] "Clouds gestantwith heat." Mrs. Browning.
guttatrap: The inspissated juice of a tree of the genus Artocarpus (A.incisa, or breadfruit tree), sometimes used in making birdlime, onaccount of its glutinous quality.
garreting: Small splinters of stone inserted into the joints of coarsemasonry. Weale.
gastralgia: Pain in the stomach or epigastrium, as in gastric disorders.
gummite: A yellow amorphous mineral, essentially a hydrated oxide ofuranium derived from the alteration of uraninite.
gnash: To strike together, as in anger or pain; as, to gnash theteeth.
grimness: Fierceness of look; sternness; crabbedness; forbiddingness.
grippe: The influenza or epidemic catarrh. Dunglison.
guzzle: To swallow liquor greedily; to drink much or frequently.Those that came to guzzle in his wine cellar. Milton.Well-seasoned bowls the gossip's spirits raise, Who, while sheguzzles, chats the doctor's praise. Roscommon.To fat the guzzling hogs with floods of whey. Gay.
gallivat: A small armed vessel, with sails and oars, -- used on theMalabar coast. A. Chalmers.
grogshop: A shop or room where strong liquors are sold and drunk; adramshop.
gynaecophore: A ventral canal or groove, in which the males of some dioecioustrematodes carry the female. See Illust. of Hæmatozoa.
glaring: Clear; notorious; open and bold; barefaced; as, a glaringcrime.-- Glar"ing*ly, adv.
graptolite: One of numerous species of slender and delicate fossils, of thegenus Graptolites and allied genera, found in the Silurian rocks.They belong to an extinct group (Graptolithina) supposed to behydroids.
gavage: Forced feeding (as of poultry or infants) by means of a tubepassed through the mouth down to the stomach.
graceful: Displaying grace or beauty in form or action; elegant; easy;agreeable in appearance; as, a graceful walk, deportment, speaker,air, act, speech.High o'er the rest in arms the graceful Turnus rode. Dryden.-- Grace"ful*ly, adv. Grace"ful*ness, n.
grebe: One of several swimming birds or divers, of the genus Colymbus(formerly Podiceps), aud allied genera, found in the northern partsof America, Europe, and Asia. They have strong, sharp bills, andlobate toes.
galling: Fitted to gall or chafe; vexing; harassing; irritating.-- Gall"ing*ly, adv.
galley: A vessel propelled by oars, whether having masts and sails ornot; as:(a) A large vessel for war and national purposes; -- common in theMiddle Ages, and down to the 17th century.(b) A name given by analogy to the Greek, Roman, and other ancientvessels propelled by oars.(c) A light, open boat used on the Thames by customhouse officers,press gangs, and also for pleasure.(d) One of the small boats carried by a man-of-war.
grinding: from Grind. Grinding frame, an English name for a cottonspinning machine.-- Grinding mill. (a) A mill for grinding grain. (b) A lapidary'slathe.
gastrovascular: Having the structure, or performing the functions, both ofdigestive and circulatory organs; as, the gastrovascular cavity ofcoelenterates.
glossiness: The condition or quality of being glossy; the luster orbrightness of a smooth surface. Boyle.
grammar: To discourse according to the rules of grammar; to use grammar.[Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
gallipot: A glazed earthen pot or vessel, used by druggists andapothecaries for containing medicines, etc.
geognosy: That part of geology which treats of the materials of theearth's structure, and its general exterior and interiorconstitution.
growan: A decomposed granite, forming a mass of gravel, as in tin lodesin Cornwall.
gynecocracy: Government by a woman, female power; gyneocracy. Bailey.
genevese: Of or pertaining to Geneva, in Switzerland; Genevan.-- n. sing. & pl.
gambit: A mode of opening the game, in which a pawn is sacrificed togain an attacking position.
gymnogen: One of a class of plants, so called by Lindley, because theovules are fertilized by direct contact of the pollen. Same asGymnosperm.
gift: A voluntary transfer of real or personal property, without anyconsideration. It can be perfected only by deed, or in case ofpersonal property, by an actual delivery of possession. Bouvier.Burrill. Gift rope (Naut), a rope extended to a boat for towing it; aguest rope.
glottis: The opening from the pharynx into the larynx or into thetrachea. See Larynx.
gittern: An instrument like a guitar. "Harps, lutes, and giternes."Chaucer.
galloway: A small horse of a breed raised at Galloway, Scotland; --called also garran, and garron.
gnar: A knot or gnarl in wood; hence, a tough, thickset man; --written also gnarr. [Archaic]He was . . . a thick gnarre. Chaucer.
galletyle: A little tile of glazed earthenware. [Obs.] "The substance ofgalletyle." Bacon.
grubble: To feel or grope in the dark. [Obs.] Dryden.
gymnocopa: A group of transparent, free-swimming Annelida, having setaeonly in the cephalic appendages.
garnishee: One who is garnished; a person upon whom garnishment has beenserved in a suit by a creditor against a debtor, such person holdingproperty belonging to the debtor, or owing him money.
grandmotherly: Like a grandmother in age or manner; kind; indulgent.
ganja: The dried hemp plant, used in India for smoking. It isextremely narcotic and intoxicating.
gavelkind: A tenure by which land descended from the father to all hissons in equal portions, and the land of a brother, dying withoutissue, descended equally to his brothers. It still prevails in thecounty of Kent. Cowell.
gape: The width of the mouth when opened, as of birds, fishes, etc.GAPES; THE GAPESThe gapes.(a) A fit of yawning.(b) A disease of young poultry and other birds, attended with muchgaping. It is caused by a parasitic nematode worm (Syngamustrachealis), in the windpipe, which obstructs the breathing. SeeGapeworm.
guacharo: A nocturnal bird of South America and Trinidad (SteatornisCaripensis, or S. steatornis); -- called also oilbird.
gier-eagle: A bird referred to in the Bible (Lev. xi. 18and Deut. xiv. 17)as unclean, probably the Egyptian vulture (Neophron percnopterus).
galley-bird: The European green woodpecker; also, the spotted woodpecker.[Prov. Eng.]
glass-rope: A remarkable vitreous sponge, of the genus Hyalonema, firstbrought from Japan. It has a long stem, consisting of a bundle oflong and large, glassy, siliceous fibers, twisted together.
galactose: A white, crystalline sugar, C6H12O6, isomeric with dextrose,obtained by the decomposition of milk sugar, and also from certaingums. When oxidized it forms mucic acid. Called also lactose (thoughit is not lactose proper).
georgian: A native of, or dweller in, Georgia.
ganger: One who oversees a gang of workmen. [R.] Mayhew.
gummy: Consisting of gum; viscous; adhesive; producing or containinggum; covered with gum or a substance resembling gum.Kindles the gummy bark of fir or pine. Milton.Then rubs his gummy eyes. Dryden.Gummy tumor (Med.), a gumma.
gyral: Pertaining to a gyrus, or convolution.
goatee: A part of a man's beard on the chin or lower lip which isallowed to grow, and trimmed so as to resemble the beard of a goat.
glaucescent: Having a somewhat glaucous appearance or nature; becomingglaucous.
girding: That with which one is girded; a girdle.Instead of a stomacher, a girding of sackcloth. Is. iii. 24.
gladiatorism: The art or practice of a gladiator.
greyhound: A slender, graceful breed of dogs, remarkable for keen sightand swiftness. It is one of the oldest varieties known, and isfigured on the Egyptian monuments. [Written also grayhound.]
gridelin: A color mixed of white, and red, or a gray violet. [Writtenalso gredaline, grizelin.] Dryden.
grogginess: Tenderness or stiffness in the foot of a horse, which causeshim to move in a hobbling manner.
greek: Of or pertaining to Greece or the Greeks; Grecian. Greekcalends. See under Calends.-- Greek Church (Eccl. Hist.), the Eastern Church; that part ofChristendom which separated from the Roman or Western Church in theninth century. It comprises the great bulk of the Christianpopulation of Russia (of which this is the established church),Greece, Moldavia, and Wallachia. The Greek Church is governed bypatriarchs and is called also the Byzantine Church.-- Greek cross. See Illust. (10) Of Cross.-- Greek Empire. See Byzantine Empire.-- Greek fire, a combustible composition which burns under water,the constituents of which are supposed to be asphalt, with niter andsulphur. Ure.-- Greek rose, the flower campion.
glochidium: The larva or young of the mussel, formerly thought to be aparasite upon the parent's gills.
guevi: One of several very small species and varieties of Africanantelopes, of the genus Cephalophus, as the Cape guevi or kleeneboc(C. pyg. mæa); -- called also pygmy antelope.
gorgonize: To have the effect of a Gorgon upon; to turn into stone; topetrify. [R.]
ganancial: Designating, pertaining to, or held under, the Spanish systemof law (called ganancial system) which controls the title anddisposition of the property acquired during marriage by the husbandor wife.
galvanograph: A copperplate produced by the method of galvanography; also, apicture printed from such a plate.
gasometry: The art or practice of measuring gases; also, the science whichtreats of the nature and properties of these elastic fluids. Coxe.
geophila: The division of Mollusca which includes the land snails andslugs.
gallipoli oil: An inferior kind of olive oil, brought from Gallipoli, inItaly.
gerocomy: That part of medicine which treats of regimen for old people.
gelose: An amorphous, gummy carbohydrate, found in Gelidium, agar-agar,and other seaweeds.
graveolence: A strong and offensive smell; rancidity. [R.] Bailey.
goracco: A paste prepared from tobacco, and smoked in hookahs in WesternIndia.
gill: An organ for aquatic respiration; a branchia.Fishes perform respiration under water by the gills. Ray.
galactopoietic: Increasing the flow of milk; milk-producing.-- n. A galactopoietic substance.
gecarcinian: A land crab of the genus Gecarcinus, or of allied genera.
glacial: Resembling ice; having the appearance and consistency of ice; -- said of certain solid compounds; as, glacial phosphoric or aceticacids. Glacial acid (Chem.), an acid of such strength or purity as tocrystallize at an ordinary temperature, in an icelike form; as aceticor carbolic acid.-- Glacial drift (Geol.), earth and rocks which have beentransported by moving ice, land ice, or icebergs; bowlder drift.-- Glacial epoch or period (Geol.), a period during which theclimate of the modern temperate regions was polar, and ice coveredlarge portions of the northern hemisphere to the mountain tops.-- Glacial theory or hypothesis. (Geol.) See Glacier theory, underGlacier.
gelation: The process of becoming solid by cooling; a cooling andsolidifying.
gambison: A defensive garment formerly in use for the body, made of clothstuffed and quilted.
gabionage: The part of a fortification built of gabions.
gallicism: A mode of speech peculiar to the French; a French idiom; also,in general, a French mode or custom.
gorgelet: A small gorget, as of a humming bird.
generation: The formation or production of any geometrical magnitude, as aline, a surface, a solid, by the motion, in accordance with amathematical law, of a point or a magnitude; as, the generation of aline or curve by the motion of a point, of a surface by a line, asphere by a semicircle, etc.
graff: A steward; an overseer.[A prince] is nothing but a servant, overseer, or graff, and not thehead, which is a title belonging only to Christ. John Knox.
gamopetalous: Having the petals united or joined so as to form a tube or cup;monopetalous.
geth: the original third pers. sing. pres. of Go. [Obs.] Chaucer.
granitification: The act or the process of forming into granite. Humble.
giglot: Giddi; light; inconstant; wanton. [Obs.] "O giglot fortune!"Shak.
guess: To make a guess or random judgment; to conjecture; -- with at,about, etcThis is the place, as well as I may guess. Milton.
garum: A sauce made of small fish. It was prized by the ancients.
galop: A kind of lively dance, in 2-4 time; also, the music to thedance.
gobelin: Pertaining to tapestry produced in the so-called Gobelin works,which have been maintained by the French Government since 1667.
gallein: A red crystalline dyestuff, obtained by heating togetherpyrogallic and phthalic acids.
giber: One who utters gibes. B. Jonson.
govern: To require to be in a particular case; as, a transitive verbgoverns a noun in the objective case; or to require (a particularcase); as, a transitive verb governs the objective case.
gigue: A piece of lively dance music, in two strains which arerepeated; also, the dance.
gastritis: Inflammation of the stomach, esp. of its mucuos membrane.
gigantomachy: A war of giants; especially, the fabulous war of the giantsagainst heaven.
gregorian: Pertaining to, or originated by, some person named Gregory,especially one of the popes of that name. Gregorian calendar, thecalendar as reformed by Pope Gregory XIII. in 1582, including themethod of adjusting the leap years so as to harmonize the civil yearwith the solar, and also the regulation of the time of Easter and themovable feasts by means of epochs. See Gregorian year (below).-- Gregorian chant (Mus.), plain song, or canto fermo, a kind ofunisonous music, according to the eight celebrated church modes, asarranged and prescribed by Pope Gregory I. (called "the Great") inthe 6th century.-- Gregorian modes, the musical scales ordained by Pope Gregory theGreat, and named after the ancient Greek scales, as Dorian, Lydian,etc.-- Gregorian telescope (Opt.), a form of reflecting telescope, namedfrom Prof. James Gregory, of Edinburgh, who perfected it in 1663. Asmall concave mirror in the axis of this telescope, having its focuscoincident with that of the large reflector, transmits the lightreceived from the latter back through a hole in its center to theeyepiece placed behind it.-- Gregorian year, the year as now reckoned according to theGregorian calendar. Thus, every year, of the current reckoning, whichis divisible by 4, except those divisible by 100 aud not by 400, has366 days; all other years have 365 days. See Bissextile, and Noteunder Style, n., 7.
gatehouse: A house connected or associated with a gate.
globigerina: A genus of small Foraminifera, which live abundantly at or nearthe surface of the sea. Their dead shells, falling to the bottom,make up a large part of the soft mud, generally found in depths below3,000 feet, and called globigerina ooze. See Illust. of Foraminifera.
gunlock: The lock of a gun, for producing the discharge. See Lock.
gapingstock: One who is an object of open-mouthed wonder.I was to be a gapingstock and a scorn to the young volunteers.Godwin.
gluey: Viscous; glutinous; of the nature of, or like, glue.
grinder: The restless flycatcher (Seisura inquieta) of Australia; --called also restless thrush and volatile thrush. It makes a noiselike a scissors grinder, to which the name alludes. Grinder's asthma,phthisis, or rot (Med.), a lung disease produced by the mechanicalirritation of the particles of steel and stone given off in theoperation of grinding.
gird: To gibe; to sneer; to break a scornful jest; to utter severesarcasms.Men of all sorts take a pride to gird at me. Shak.
gametophyte: In the alternation of generations in plants, that generation orphase which bears sex organs. In the lower plants, as the algæ, thegametophyte is the conspicuous part of the plant body; in mosses itis the so-called moss plant; in ferns it is reduced to a small, earlyperishing body; and in seed plants it is usually microscopic orrudimentary.
gradational: By regular steps or gradations; of or pertaining to gradation.
grassation: A wandering about with evil intentions; a rioting. [Obs. & R.]Feltham.
gardant: Turning the head towards the spectator, but not the body; --said of a lion or other beast.
gladstone: A four-wheeled pleasure carriage with two inside seats, calashtop, and seats for driver and footman.
galactometer: An instrument for ascertaining the quality of milk (i.e., itsrichness in cream) by determining its specific gravity; a lactometer.
gloppen: To surprise or astonish; to be startled or astonished. [Prov.Eng.] Halliwell.
gunreach: The reach or distance to which a gun will shoot; gunshot.
goosewing: One of the clews or lower corners of a course or a topsail whenthe middle part or the rest of the sail is furled.
glut: To eat gluttonously or to satiety.Like three horses that have broken fence, And glutted all night longbreast-deep in corn. Tennyson.
ganch: To drop from a high place upon sharp stakes or hooks, as theTurks dropped malefactors, by way of punishment.Ganching, which is to let fall from on high upon hooks, and there tohang until they die. Sandys.
gulfy: Full of whirlpools or gulfs. Chapman.
goatskin: The skin of a goat, or leather made from it.-- a.
gallery: A frame, like a balcony, projecting from the stern or quarterof a ship, and hence called stern galery or quarter gallry, -- seldomfound in vessels built since 1850.
gleg: Quick of perception; alert; sharp. [Scot.] Jamieson.
gothamist: A wiseacre; a person deficient in wisdom; -- so called fromGotham, in Nottinghamshire, England, noted for some pleasantblunders. Bp. Morton.
goutiness: The state of being gouty; gout.
grammarianism: The principles, practices, or peculiarities of grammarians.[R.]
gadhelic: Of or pertaining to that division of the Celtic languages,which includes the Irish, Gaelic, and Manx. J. Peile.
glancingly: In a glancing manner; transiently; incidentally; indirectly.Hakewill.
grapeless: Wanting grapes or the flavor of grapes.
grossulin: A vegetable jelly, resembling pectin, found in gooseberries(Ribes Grossularia) and other fruits.
gastroenteritis: Inflammation of the lining membrane of the stomach and theintestines.
graphics: The art or the science of drawing; esp. of drawing according tomathematical rules, as in perspective, projection, and the like.
graftage: The science of grafting, including the various methods ofpractice and details of operation.
gainly: Handily; readily; dexterously; advantageously. [Obs.] Dr. H.More.
graveyard: A yard or inclosure for the interment of the dead; a cemetery.
get-penny: Something which gets or gains money; a successful affair.[Colloq.] Chapman.
gentianine: A bitter, crystallizable substance obtained from gentian.
gaudiness: The quality of being gaudy. Whitlock.
grafting: The act or method of weaving a cover for a ring, rope end, etc.
glazy: Having a glazed appearance; -- said of the fractured surface ofsome kinds of pin iron.
gyratory: Moving in a circle, or spirally; revolving; whirling around.
gaff-topsail: A small triangular sail having its foot extended upon the gaffand its luff upon the topmast.
grim: Of forbidding or fear-inspiring aspect; fierce; stern; surly;cruel; frightful; horrible.Whose grim aspect sets every joint a-shaking. Shak.The ridges of grim war. Milton.
gaduin: A yellow or brown amorphous substance, of indifferent nature,found in cod-liver oil.
geniohyoid: Of or pertaining to the chin and hyoid bone; as, the geniohyoidmuscle.
gelding: A castrated animal; -- usually applied to a horse, but formerlyused also of the human male.They went down both into the water, Philip and the gelding, andPhilip baptized him. Wyclif (Acts viii. 38).
guerite: A projecting turret for a sentry, as at the salient angles ofworks, or the acute angles of bastions.
gatch: Plaster as used in Persian architecture and decorative art.
grin: A snare; a gin. [Obs.]Like a bird that hasteth to his grin. Remedy of Love.
glucose: Any one of a large class of sugars, isometric with glucoseproper, and including levulose, galactose, etc.
galbe: The general outward form of any solid object, as of a column ora vase.
glazing: Transparent, or semitransparent, colors passed thinly overother colors, to modify the effect.
grille: A lattice or grating.The grille which formed part of the gate. L. Oliphant.
grossular: Pertaining too, or resembling, a gooseberry; as, grossulargarnet.
glee club: A club or company organized for singing glees, and (byextension) part songs, ballads, etc.
gazette: A newspaper; a printed sheet published periodically; esp., theofficial journal published by the British government, and containinglegal and state notices.
glazier: One whose business is to set glass. Glazier's diamond. Seeunder Diamond.
gutta: One of a series of ornaments, in the form of a frustum of acone, attached to the lower part of the triglyphs, and also to thelower faces of the mutules, in the Doric order; -- called alsocampana, and drop. Gutta serena Etym: [L., lit. serene or clear drop](Med.), amaurosis.-- Guttæ band (Arch.), the listel or band from which the guttæ hang.
granulite: A whitish, granular rock, consisting of feldspar and quartzintimately mixed; -- sometimes called whitestone, and leptynite.
goosander: A species of merganser (M. merganser) of Northern Europe andAmerica; -- called also merganser, dundiver, sawbill, sawneb,shelduck, and sheldrake. See Merganser.
gerund: A verbal noun ending in -e, preceded by to and usually denotingpurpose or end; -- called also the dative infinitive; as, "Ic hæbbemete tô etanne" (I have meat to eat.) In Modern English the name hasbeen applied to verbal or participal nouns in -ing denoting atransitive action; e. g., by throwing a stone.
gelidness: The state of being gelid; gelidity.
gull: To deceive; to cheat; to mislead; to trick; to defraud.The rulgar, gulled into rebellion, armed. Dryden.I'm not gulling him for the emperor's service. Coleridge.
godwit: One of several species of long-billed, wading birds of thegenus Limosa, and family Tringidæ. The European black-tailed godwit(Limosa limosa), the American marbled godwit (L. fedoa), theHudsonian godwit (L. hæmastica), and others, are valued as gamebirds. Called also godwin.
grolier: The name by which Jean Grolier de Servier (1479-1565), a Frenchbibliophile, is commonly known; -- used in naming a certain style ofbinding, a design, etc.
glomuliferous: Having small clusters of minutely branched coral-likeexcrescences. M. C. Cooke.
got: imp. & p. p. of Get. See Get.
glebe: The land belonging, or yielding revenue, to a parish church orecclesiastical benefice.
glaucic: Of or pertaining to the Glaucium or horned poppy; -- formerlyapplied to an acid derived from it, now known to be fumaric acid.
germinate: To sprout; to bud; to shoot; to begin to vegetate, as a plantor its seed; to begin to develop, as a germ. Bacon.
geodetically: In a geodetic manner; according to geodesy.
gleamy: Darting beams of light; casting light in rays; flashing;coruscating.In brazed arms, that cast a gleamy ray, Swift through the town thewarrior bends his way. Pope.
gelsemium: A genus of climbing plants. The yellow (false) jasmine(Gelsemium sempervirens) is a native of the Southern United States.It has showy and deliciously fragrant flowers.
glandulous: Containing glands; consisting of glands; pertaining to glands;resembling glands.
grandiosity: The state or quality of being grandiose,
glass-crab: The larval state (Phyllosoma) of the genus Palinurus and alliedgenera. It is remarkable for its strange outlines, thinness, andtransparency. See Phyllosoma.
gastro-: A combining form from the Gr. gastrocolic, gastrocele,gastrotomy.
gastroscopy: Examination of the abdomen or stomach, as with the gastroscope.
gorgeous: Imposing through splendid or various colors; showy; fine;magnificent.Cloud-land, gorgeous land. Coleridge.Gogeous as the sun at midsummer. Shak.-- Gor"geous*ly, adv.-- Gor"geous*ness, n.
gravel: A deposit of small calculous concretions in the kidneys and theurinary or gall bladder; also, the disease of which they are asymptom. Gravel powder, a coarse gunpowder; pebble powder.
galeopithecus: A genus of flying Insectivora, formerly called flying lemurs.See Colugo.
goody: An American fish; the lafayette or spot.
glucinum: A rare metallic element, of a silver white color, and lowspecific gravity (2.1), resembling magnesium. It never occursnaturally in the free state, but is always combined, usually withsilica or alumina, or both; as in the minerals phenacite,chrysoberyl, beryl or emerald, euclase, and danalite. It was namedfrom its oxide glucina, which was known long before the element wasisolated. Symbol Gl. Atomic weight 9.1. Called also beryllium.[Formerly written also glucinium.]
gigantesque: Befitting a giant; bombastic; magniloquent.The sort of mock-heroic gigantesque With which we bantered littleLilia first. Tennyson.
gravenstein: A kind of fall apple, marked with streaks of deep red andorange, and of excellent flavor and quality.
goatish: Characteristic of a goat; goatlike.Give your chaste body up to the embraces Of goatish lust. Massinger.-- Goat"ish*ly, adv.-- Goat"ish*ness, n.
greenhouse: A house in which tender plants are cultivated and shelteredfrom the weather.
gringo: Among Spanish Americans, a foreigner, esp. an Englishman orAmerican; -- often used as a term of reproach.
glama: A copious gummy secretion of the humor of the eyelids, inconsequence of some disorder; blearedness; lippitude.
gumboil: A small suppurting inflamed spot on the gum.
gaulish: Pertaining to ancient France, or Gaul; Gallic. [R.]
giraffe: An African ruminant (Camelopardalis giraffa) related to thedeers and antelopes, but placed in a family by itself; thecamelopard. It is the tallest of animals, being sometimes twenty feetfrom the hoofs to the top of the head. Its neck is very long, and itsfore legs are much longer than its hind legs.
goggle-eyed: Having prominent and distorted or rolling eyes. Ascham.
gymnosperm: A plant that bears naked seeds (i. e., seeds not inclosed in anovary), as the common pine and hemlock. Cf. Angiosperm.
galatea: A kind of striped cotton fabric, usually of superior qualityand striped with blue or red on white.
greith: To make ready; -- often used reflexively. [Obs.] Chaucer.
gye: To guide; to govern. [Obs.]Discreet enough his country for to gye. Chaucer.
gourmet: A connoisseur in eating and drinking; an epicure.
glandular: Containing or supporting glands; consisting of glands;pertaining to glands.
graafian: Pertaining to, or discovered by, Regnier de Graaf, a Dutchphysician. Graafian follicles or vesicles, small cavities in whichthe ova are developed in the ovaries of mammals, and by the burstingof which they are discharged.
geminy: Twins; a pair; a couple. [Obs.] Shak.
guidguid: A South American ant bird of the genus Hylactes; -- called alsobarking bird.
generative: Having the power of generating, propagating, originating, orproducing. "That generative particle." Bentley.
gladiate: Sword-shaped; resembling a sword in form, as the leaf of theiris, or of the gladiolus.
gallfly: An insect that deposits its eggs in plants, and occasionsgalls, esp. any small hymenopteran of the genus Cynips and alliedgenera. See Illust. of Gall.
golden state: California; -- a nickname alluding to its rich gold deposits.
geoscopy: Knowledge of the earth, ground, or soil, obtained byinspection. Chambers.
gaditanian: Of or relating to Cadiz, in Spain.-- n.
geolatry: The worship of the earth. G. W. Cox. The Geological Series.
girtline: A gantline. Hammock girtline, a line rigged for hanging outhammocks to dry.
genital: Pertaining to generation, or to the generative organs. Genitalcord (Anat.), a cord developed in the fetus by the union of portionsof the Wolffian and Müllerian ducts and giving rise to parts of theurogenital passages in both sexes.
goitrous: Pertaining to the goiter; affected with the goiter; of thenature of goiter or bronchocele.Let me not be understood as insinuating that the inhabitants ingeneral are either goitrous or idiots. W. Coxe.
grimme: A West African antelope (Cephalophus rufilotus) of a deep baycolor, with a broad dorsal stripe of black; -- called alsoconquetoon.
gratulate: To salute with declaration of joy; to congratulate. [R.] Shak.
gasiform: Having a form of gas; gaseous.
grounding: The act, method, or process of laying a groundwork orfoundation; hence, elementary instruction; the act or process ofapplying a ground, as of color, to wall paper, cotton cloth, etc.; abasis.
grouser: (Dredging, Pile Driving, etc.) A pointed timber attached to aboat and sliding vertically, to thrust into the ground as a means ofanchorage.
game: Crooked; lame; as, a game leg. [Colloq.]
gyrfalcon: One of several species and varieties of large Arctic falcons,esp. Falco rusticolus and the white species F. Islandicus, both ofwhich are circumpolar. The black and the gray are varieties of theformer. See Illust. of Accipiter. [Written also gerfalcon,gierfalcon, and jerfalcon.]
gally: To frighten; to worry. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] T. Brown.
geck: To jeer; to show contempt. Sir W. Scott.
glyphography: A process similar to etching, in which, by means of voltaicelectricity, a raised copy of a drawing is made, so that it can beused to print from.
glower: to look intently; to stare angrily or with a scowl. Thackeray.
gaoler: The keeper of a jail. See Jailer.
galaxy: The Milky Way; that luminous tract, or belt, which is seen atnight stretching across the heavens, and which is composed ofinnumerable stars, so distant and blended as to be distinguishableonly with the telescope. The term has recently been used for remoteclusters of stars. Nichol.
graminaceous: Pertaining to, or resembling, the grasses; gramineous; as,graminaceous plants.
goaf: That part of a mine from which the mineral has been partiallyor wholly removed; the waste left in old workings; -- called also gob. To work the goaf or gob, to remove the pillars of mineral matterpreviously left to support the roof, and replace them with props.Ure.
grangerism: The practice of illustrating a particular book by engravingscollected from other books.
goffer: To plait, flute, or crimp. See Gauffer. Clarke.
goliath beetle: Any species of Goliathus, a genus of very large and handsomeAfrican beetles.
gnarly: Full of knots; knotty; twisted; crossgrained.
gunwale: The upper edge of a vessel's or boat's side; the uppermost waleof a ship (not including the bulwarks); or that piece of timber whichreaches on either side from the quarter-deck to the forecastle, beingthe uppermost bend, which finishes the upper works of the hull.[Written also gunnel.]
grooving: The act of forming a groove or grooves; a groove, or collectionof grooves.
gesticulate: To make gestures or motions, as in speaking; to use postures.Sir T. Herbert.
glycose: One of a class of carbohydrates having from three to nine atomsof carbon in the molecules and having the constitution either of analdehyde alcohol or of a ketone alcohol. Most glycoses have hydrogenand oxygen present in the proportion to form water, while the numberof carbon atoms is usually equal to the number of atoms of oxygen.
galvanometer: An instrument or apparatus for measuring the intensity of anelectric current, usually by the deflection of a magnetic needle.Differential galvanometer. See under Differental, a.-- Sine galvanometer, Cosine galvanometer, Tangent galvanometer(Elec.), a galvanometer in which the sine, cosine, or tangentrespectively, of the angle through which the needle is deflected, isproportional to the strength of the current passed through theinstrument.
gash: To make a gash, or long, deep incision in; -- applied chieflyto incisions in flesh.Grievously gashed or gored to death. Hayward.
greenstone: A name formerly applied rather loosely to certain dark-coloredigneous rocks, including diorite, diabase, etc.
gadic: Pertaining to, or derived from, the cod (Gadus); -- applied toan acid obtained from cod-liver oil, viz., gadic acid.
gemmiparous: Producing buds; reproducing by buds. See Gemmation, 1.
guardenage: Guardianship. [Obs. & R.] " His tuition and guardenage."Holland.
great-grandchild: The child of one's grandson or granddaughter.
guttulous: In droplike form. [Obs.]In its [hail's] guttulous descent from the air. Sir T. Browne.
gemminess: The state or quality of being gemmy; spruceness; smartness.
gradate: To bring to a certain strength or grade of concentration; as,to gradate a saline solution.
gynocracy: Female government; gynecocracy.The aforesaid state has repeatedly changed from absolute despotism torepublicanism, not forgetting the intermediate stages of oligarchy,limited monarchy, and even gynocracy; for I myself remember Alsatiagoverned for nearly nine months by an old fishwoman. Sir H. Scott.
gallize: In wine making, to add water and sugar to (unfermented grapejuice) so as to increase the quantity of wine produced. --Gal`li*za"tion (#), n.
gentile: One of a non-Jewish nation; one neither a Jew nor a Christian;a worshiper of false gods; a heathen.
goatsucker: One of several species of insectivorous birds, belonging toCaprimulgus and allied genera, esp. the European species (CaprimulgusEuropæus); -- so called from the mistaken notion that it sucks goats.The European species is also goat-milker, goat owl, goat chaffer,fern owl, night hawk, nightjar, night churr, churr-owl, gnat hawk,and dorhawk .
gooseberry: Any thorny shrub of the genus Ribes; also, the edible berriesof such shrub. There are several species, of which Ribes Grossulariais the one commonly cultivated.
genesiolgy: The doctrine or science of generation.
grindelia: The dried stems and leaves of tarweed (Grindelia), used as aremedy in asthma and bronchitis.
glycolic: Pertaining to, or derived from, glycol; as, glycolic ether;glycolic acid. Glycolic acid (Chem.), an organic acid, foundnaturally in unripe grapes and in the leaves of the wild grape(Ampelopsis quinquefolia), and produced artificially in many ways, asby the oxidation of glycol, -- whence its name. It is a sirupy, orwhite crystalline, substance, HO.CH2.CO2H, has the properties both ofan alcohol and an acid, and is a type of the hydroxy acids; -- calledalso hydroxyacetic acid.
grandiloquence: The use of lofty words or phrases; bombast; -- usually in a badsense.The sin of grandiloquence or tall talking. Thackeray,
grandam: An old woman; specifically, a grandmother. Shak.
globe: To gather or form into a globe.
genuine: Belonging to, or proceeding from, the original stock; native;hence, not counterfeit, spurious, false, or adulterated; authentic;real; natural; true; pure; as, a genuine text; a genuine production;genuine materials. "True, genuine night." Dryden.
gaultheria: A genus of ericaceous shrubs with evergreen foliage, and,often, edible berries. It includes the American winter-green(Gaultheria procumbens), and the larger-fruited salal of NorthwesternAmerica (Gaultheria Shallon).
gainpain: Bread-gainer; -- a term applied in the Middle Ages to the swordof a hired soldier.
georama: A hollow globe on the inner surface of which a map of the worldis depicted, to be examined by one standing inside.
gateway: A passage through a fence or wall; a gate; also, a frame, arch,etc., in which a gate in hung, or a structure at an entrance or gatedesigned for ornament or defense.
grazier: One who pastures cattle, and rears them for market.The inhabitants be rather . . . graziers than plowmen. Stow.
gloss: To give a superficial luster or gloss to; to make smooth andshining; as, to gloss cloth.The glossed and gleamy wave. J. R. Drake.
gastrointestinal: Of or pertaining to the stomach and intestines; gastroenteric.
gammoning: The lashing or iron band by which the bowsprit of a vessel issecured to the stem to opposite the lifting action of the forestays.Gammoning fashion, in the style of gammoning lashing, that is, havingthe turns of rope crossed.-- Gammoning hole (Naut.), a hole cut through the knee of the headof a vessel for the purpose of gammoning the bowsprit.
griff: An arrangement of parallel bars for lifting the hooked wireswhich raise the warp threads in a loom for weaving figured goods.Knight.
gromwell: A plant of the genus Lithospermum (L. arvense), anciently used,because of its stony pericarp, in the cure of gravel. The Germangromwell is the Stellera. [Written also gromill.]
grandfatherly: Like a grandfather in age or manner; kind; benignant;indulgent.He was a grandfatherly sort of personage. Hawthorne.
gusty: Subject to, or characterized by, gusts or squalls; windy;stormy; tempestuous.Upon a raw and gusty day. Shak.
grovy: Pertaining to, or resembling, a grove; situated in, orfrequenting, groves. Dampier.
godroon: An ornament produced by notching or carving a rounded molding.
globulimeter: An instrument for measuring the number of red blood corpusclesin the blood.
graffiti: Inscriptions, figure drawings, etc., found on the walls ofancient sepulchers or ruins, as in the Catacombs, or at Pompeii.
grandevous: Of great age; aged; longlived. [R.] Bailey.
gular: Pertaining to the gula or throat; as, gular plates. See Illust.of Bird, and Bowfin.
grapple: To use a grapple; to contend in close fight; to attach one'sself as if by a grapple, as in wrestling; to close; to seize oneanother. To grapple with, to enter into contest with, resolutely andcourageously.And in my standard bear the arms of York, To grapple with the houseof Lancaster. Shak.
geropigia: A mixture composed of unfermented grape juice, brandy, sugar,etc., for adulteration of wines. [Written also jerupigia.]
gaber-lunzie: A beggar with a wallet; a licensed beggar. [Scot.] Sir W.Scott.
gravelly: Abounding with gravel; consisting of gravel; as, a gravellysoil.
gawky: Foolish and awkward; clumsy; clownish; as, gawky behavior.-- n. A fellow who is awkward from being overgrown, or fromstupidity, a gawk.
gam: To have a gam with; to pay a visit to, esp. among whalers atsea.
gorcock: The moor cock, or red grouse. See Grouse. [Prov. Eng.]
glassware: Ware, or articles collectively, made of glass.
gnostic: Of or pertaining to Gnosticism or its adherents; as, theGnostic heresy.
gymnodont: One of a group of plectognath fishes (Gymnodontes), having theteeth and jaws consolidated into one or two bony plates, on each jaw,as the diodonts and tetradonts. See Bur fish, Globefish, Diodon.
georgian architecture: British or British colonial architecture of the period of thefour Georges, especially that of the period before 1800.
game fowl: A handsome breed of the common fowl, remarkable for the greatcourage and pugnacity of the males.
gladness: State or quality of being glad; pleasure; joyful satisfaction;cheerfulness.They . . . did eat their meat with gladness and singleness of heart.Acts ii. 46.
globiferous: Having a round or globular tip.
gryphaea: A genus of cretaceous fossil shells allied to the oyster.
geisha: A Japanese singing and dancing girl.
ghastful: Fit to make one aghast; dismal. [Obs.] -- Ghast"ful*ly, adv.
graphitic: Pertaining to, containing, derived from, or resembling,graphite. Graphitic acid (Chem.), an organic acid, so called becauseobtained by the oxidation of graphite; -- usually called melliticacid.-- Graphitic carbon, in iron or steel, that portion of the carbonwhich is present as graphite. Raymond.
gulleting: A system of excavating by means of gullets or channels.
gyration: One of the whorls of a spiral univalve shell. Center ofgyration. (Mech.) See under Center.-- Radius of gyration the distance between the axis of a rotatingbody and its center of gyration. Rankine.
grayling: A European fish (Thymallus vulgaris), allied to the trout, buthaving a very broad dorsal fin; -- called also umber. It inhabitscold mountain streams, and is valued as a game fish.And here and there a lusty trout, And here and there a grayling.Tennyson.
gynobase: A dilated base or receptacle, supporting a multilocular ovary.
gambrel: To truss or hang up by means of a gambrel. Beau. & Fl.
garb: A sheaf of grain (wheat, unless otherwise specified).
grammaticaster: A petty grammarian; a grammatical pedant or pretender.My noble Neophite, my little grammaticaster. B. Jonson.
gopher state: Minnesota; -- a nickname alluding to the abundance of gophers.
genearch: The chief of a family or tribe.
gauziness: The quality of being gauzy; flimsiness. Ruskin.
glycerite: A medicinal preparation made by mixing or dissolving asubstance in glycerin.
groundless: Without ground or foundation; wanting cause or reason forsupport; not authorized; false; as, groundless fear; a groundlessreport or assertion.-- Ground"less*ly, adv.-- Ground"less*ness, n.
gin: Against; near by; towards; as, gin night. [Scot.] A. Ross(1778).
glume: The bracteal covering of the flowers or seeds of grain andgrasses; esp., an outer husk or bract of a spikelt. Gray.
grow: To cause to grow; to cultivate; to produce; as, to grow a crop;to grow wheat, hops, or tobacco. Macaulay.
galician: Of or pertaining to Galicia, in Spain, or to Galicia, thekingdom of Austrian Poland.-- n.
gila monster: A large tuberculated lizard (Heloderma suspectum) native of thedry plains of Arizona, New Mexico, etc. It is the only lizard knownto have venomous teeth.
gymnocarpous: Naked-fruited, the fruit either smooth or not adherent to theperianth. Gray.
graptolitic: Of or pertaining to graptolites; containing graptolites; as, agraptolitic slate.
guhr: A loose, earthy deposit from water, found in the cavities orclefts of rocks, mostly white, but sometimes red or yellow, from amixture of clay or ocher. P. Cleaveland.
giaour: An infidel; -- a term applied by Turks to disbelievers in theMohammedan religion, especially Christrians. Byron.
grassplot: A plot or space covered with grass; a lawn. "Here on thisgrassplot." Shak.
glycoluric: Pertaining to, derived from, glycol and urea; as, glycoluricacid, which is called also hydantoic acid.
gymnonoti: The order of fishes which includes the Gymnotus or electricaleel. The dorsal fin is wanting.
gabert: A lighter, or vessel for inland navigation. [Scot.] Jamieson.
germinant: Sprouting; sending forth germs or buds.
glockenspiel: An instrument, originally a series of bells on an iron rod, nowa set of flat metal bars, diatonically tuned, giving a bell-like tonewhen played with a mallet; a carillon.
gypsywort: A labiate plant (the Lycopus Europæus). Gypsies are said tostain their skin with its juice.
governable: Capable of being governed, or subjected to authority;controllable; manageable; obedient. Locke.
gander: The male of any species of goose.
gymnocyte: (Biol.) A cytode without a proper cell wall, but with anucleus. Haeckel.
guaranine: An alkaloid extracted from guarana. Same as Caffeine.
gauss: The C.G.S. unit of density of magnetic field, equal to a fieldof one line of force per square centimeter, being thus adopted as aninternational unit at Paris in 1900; sometimes used as a unit ofintensity of magnetic field. It was previously suggested as a unit ofmagnetomotive force.
ghastly: In a ghastly manner; hideously.Staring full ghastly like a strangled man. Shak.
glyoxaline: A white, crystalline, organic base, C3H4N2, produced by theaction of ammonia on glyoxal, and forming the origin of a large classof derivatives hence, any one of the series of which glyoxaline is atype; -- called also oxaline.
glutazine: A nitrogenous substance, forming a heavy, sandy powder, whiteor nearly so. It is a derivative of pyridine.
genuflect: To bend the knee, as in worship.
glyceric: Pertaining to, or derived from, glycerin. Glyceric acid(Chem.), an organic acid, obtained by the partial oxidation ofglycerin, as a thick liquid. It is a hydroxyl derivative of propionicacid, and has both acid and alcoholic properties.
garboard: One of the planks next the keel on the outside, which form agarboard strake. Garboard strake or streak, the first range or strakeof planks laid on a ship's bottom next the keel. Totten.
greenback: One of the legal tender notes of the United States; -- firstissued in 1862, and having the devices on the back printed with greenink, to prevent alterations and counterfeits.
golf: A game played with a small ball and a bat or club crooked atthe lower end. He who drives the ball into each of a series of smallholes in the ground and brings it into the last hole with the feweststrokes is the winner. [Scot.] Strutt.
gowned: Dressed in a gown; clad.Gowned in pure white, that fitted to the shape. Tennyson.
genitive: Of or pertaining to that case (as the second case of Latin andGreek nouns) which expresses source or possession. It corresponds tothe possessive case in English.
grandeeship: The rank or estate of a grandee; lordship. H. Swinburne.
guenon: One of several long-tailed Oriental monkeys, of the genusCercocebus, as the green monkey and grivet.
gurry: An alvine evacuation; also, refuse matter. [Obs. or Local]Holland.
gimp: Smart; spruce; trim; nice. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
geocronite: A lead-gray or grayish blue mineral with a metallic luster,consisting of sulphur, antimony, and lead, with a small proportion ofarsenic.
garment: Any article of clothing, as a coat, a gown, etc.No man putteth a piece of new cloth unto old garment. Matt. ix. 16.
gayal: A Southern Asiatic species of wild cattle (Bibos frontalis).
gardon: A European cyprinoid fish; the id.
geoduck: A gigantic clam (Glycimeris generosa) of the Pacific coast ofNorth America, highly valued as an article of food.
gainsay: To contradict; to deny; to controvert; to dispute; to forbid.I will give you a mouth and wisdom which all your adversaries shallnot be able to gainsay nor resist. Luke xxi. 15.The just gods gainsay That any drop thou borrow'dst from thy mother,My sacred aunt, should by my mortal sword Be drained. Shak.
gougeshell: A sharp-edged, tubular, marine shell, of the genus Vermetus;also, the pinna. See Vermetus.
genethlialogy: Divination as to the destinies of one newly born; the act orart of casting nativities; astrology.
galvanization: The act of process of galvanizing.
gog: Haste; ardent desire to go. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
